~ David Jao

Tools for Enumeration

Main interest: counting the size of various sets.

Let us recall the elementary operations that can be performed with sets. Let A,BA, BA,B be finite sets. We have the following operations:

UNION: A∪B={x∣x∈A or x∈B}A\cup B = \{x | x \in A \text{ or } x \in B\}A∪B={x∣x∈A or x∈B}

INTERSECTION: A∩B={x∣x∈A and x∈B}A\cap B = \{x | x\in A \text{ and } x \in B\}A∩B={x∣x∈A and x∈B}

In order to count the size of a set, one of the approaches used is to build that
set using unions of smaller sets, whose sizes are known. It is important,
therefore, to understand the relationship between the cardinality of a set and
the cardinalities of the sets that it is built from.

Most readers should be aware of the following identity: ∣A∪B∣=∣A∣+∣B∣−∣A∩B∣|A\cup B| = |A| + |B| - |A\cap B|∣A∪B∣=∣A∣+∣B∣−∣A∩B∣ which is of utmost importance when it comes to counting the size of
sets as it provides a relationship between the cardinality of a set A∪BA\cup BA∪B
and the cardinalities ∣A∣|A|∣A∣ and ∣B∣|B|∣B∣. A much simpler case arises when A∩B=∅A\cap B = \emptysetA∩B=∅ i.e. when A∪BA\cup BA∪B is a disjoint union- the identity reduces to
∣A∪B∣=∣A∣+∣B∣|A\cup B| = |A| + |B|∣A∪B∣=∣A∣+∣B∣.

This identity can be extended to a more general one. Given sets A1,…,AnA_1, \dots, A_nA1​,…,An​ with Ai∩Aj=∅A_i\cap A_j = \emptysetAi​∩Aj​=∅ for 1≤i<j≤n1 \leq i < j \leq n1≤i<j≤n, we have ∣A1∪⋯∪An∣=∑j=1n∣Aj∣|A_1\cup \dots \cup A_n| = \sum_{j=1}^n |A_j|∣A1​∪⋯∪An​∣=∑j=1n​∣Aj​∣. This is readily proven by induction on
nnn. In the case of n=2n=2n=2, the identity holds, as seen above. Now, assuming that
the identity holds for some n>2n > 2n>2, we can verify it for case n+1n+1n+1:

∣A1∪⋯∪An∪An+1∣=∣(A1∪⋯∪An)∪An+1∣=∣(A1∪⋯∪An)∣+∣An+1∣−∣(A1∪⋯∪An)∩An+1∣=∑i=1n∣Ai∣+∣An+1∣−∣(A1∩An+1)∪⋯∪(An∩An+1)∣=∑i=1n+1∣Ai∣−∣∅∣=∑i=1n+1∣Ai∣\begin{aligned} |A_1\cup \dots \cup A_n \cup A_{n+1}| &= |(A_1\cup \dots \cup A_n) \cup A_{n+1}|\\ &= |(A_1\cup \dots \cup A_n)| + |A_{n+1}| - |(A_1\cup \dots \cup A_n)\cap A_{n+1}|\\ &= \sum_{i=1}^n |A_i| + |A_{n+1}| - |(A_1 \cap A_{n+1})\cup \dots \cup (A_n\cap A_{n+1})|\\ &= \sum_{i=1}^{n+1} |A_i| - |\emptyset| = \sum_{i=1}^{n+1} |A_i| \end{aligned}∣A1​∪⋯∪An​∪An+1​∣​=∣(A1​∪⋯∪An​)∪An+1​∣=∣(A1​∪⋯∪An​)∣+∣An+1​∣−∣(A1​∪⋯∪An​)∩An+1​∣=i=1∑n​∣Ai​∣+∣An+1​∣−∣(A1​∩An+1​)∪⋯∪(An​∩An+1​)∣=i=1∑n+1​∣Ai​∣−∣∅∣=i=1∑n+1​∣Ai​∣​

This allows us to state one of the techniques used for problem solving in this
course: Recognizing that a set can be expressed as a disjoint union of other
sets. The general identity derived above proves to be helpful in this
technique. Now, back to set operations:

CARTESIAN PRODUCT: A×B={(a,b)∣a∈A,b∈B}A\times B = \{(a, b) | a \in A, b \in B\}A×B={(a,b)∣a∈A,b∈B}. This object
has the property that ∣A×B∣=∣A∣⋅∣B∣|A \times B| = |A|\cdot |B|∣A×B∣=∣A∣⋅∣B∣.

CARTESIAN POWER: Ak={(a1,…,ak)∣a1∈A,…,ak∈A}A^k = \{(a_1, \dots, a_k) | a_1\in A, \dots, a_k\in A\}Ak={(a1​,…,ak​)∣a1​∈A,…,ak​∈A}.
This object can be expressed alternatively as the cartesian product of AAA with
itself, kkk times and has the property that ∣Ak∣=∣A∣k|A^k| = |A|^k∣Ak∣=∣A∣k.

Example: Let S={0,1}k={(z1,…,zk)∣z1,…,zk∈{0,1}}S=\{0,1\}^k = \{(z_1, \dots, z_k) | z_1, \dots, z_k \in \{0,1\}\}S={0,1}k={(z1​,…,zk​)∣z1​,…,zk​∈{0,1}}. SSS is called the set of kkk-tuples of bits. Using the property of
the cartesian product outlined above, we see that ∣S∣=∣{0,1}k∣=∣{0,1}∣k=2k|S| =|\{0,1\}^k| = |\{0,1\}|^k = 2^k∣S∣=∣{0,1}k∣=∣{0,1}∣k=2k.

Example: Let S={(z1,z2,z3)∈{0,1}3∣z1+z2+z3≤1}S=\{(z_1, z_2, z_3)\in \{0,1\}^3 | z_1 + z_2 + z_3 \leq 1\}S={(z1​,z2​,z3​)∈{0,1}3∣z1​+z2​+z3​≤1}.
Find ∣S∣|S|∣S∣. In this case, it may be easy to write out the elements of SSS and
count them but we shall use the method of expressing SSS as a union of 2
disjoint sets to see how it works.

We can write S=A∪BS=A\cup BS=A∪B where A={(z1,z2,z3)∈{0,1}3∣z1+z2+z3=0}A=\{(z_1,z_2,z_3)\in \{0,1\}^3 | z_1 + z_2 + z_3 = 0\}A={(z1​,z2​,z3​)∈{0,1}3∣z1​+z2​+z3​=0} and B={(z1,z2,z3)∈{0,1}3∣z1+z2+z3=1}B=\{(z_1,z_2,z_3)\in \{0,1\}^3 | z_1 + z_2 + z_3 = 1\}B={(z1​,z2​,z3​)∈{0,1}3∣z1​+z2​+z3​=1}. So clearly,
A∩B=∅A\cap B = \emptysetA∩B=∅ by the definition of AAA and BBB. This allows us to say
that ∣S∣=∣A∣+∣B∣|S| = |A| + |B|∣S∣=∣A∣+∣B∣.

Now, we can count: A={(0,0,0)}A = \{(0,0,0)\}A={(0,0,0)} so ∣A∣=1|A| = 1∣A∣=1 and B={(1,0,0),(0,1,0),(0,0,1)}B = \{(1,0,0), (0,1,0), (0,0,1)\}B={(1,0,0),(0,1,0),(0,0,1)} so that ∣B∣=3|B| = 3∣B∣=3. Therefore, ∣S∣=1+3=4|S| = 1 + 3 = 4∣S∣=1+3=4.

Binomial Coefficients

These come up a lot when it comes to enumeration and counting problems so getting
comfortable with the binomial coefficients is important.

Definition: Sk,n:={Ω∈{1,…,n}∣∣Ω∣=k}S_{k,n} := \{\Omega \in \{1, \dots, n\} | |\Omega| = k\}Sk,n​:={Ω∈{1,…,n}∣∣Ω∣=k}. This
will prove to be an important set definition once some of its properties have
been uncovered. Sk,nS_{k,n}Sk,n​ is the set of all subsets of {1,…,n}\{1, \dots, n\}{1,…,n} of
size kkk.

In general, this set can be used to understand many real-life situations e.g.
the number of 5-card hands from a standard deck of 52 cards is ∣S5,52∣|S_{5,52}|∣S5,52​∣.

THEOREM: let 0≤k≤n0 \leq k \leq n0≤k≤n. Then ∣Sk,n∣=n(n−1)⋯(n−k+1)k!|S_{k,n}| = \frac{n(n-1)\cdots(n - k + 1)}{k!}∣Sk,n​∣=k!n(n−1)⋯(n−k+1)​.

Proof: Let Lk,n:={(a1,…,ak)∈{1,…,n}k∣ai≠aj for i≠j}L_{k,n} := \{(a_1,\dots,a_k)\in \{1,\dots,n\}^k | a_i\neq a_j \text{ for } i\neq j \}Lk,n​:={(a1​,…,ak​)∈{1,…,n}k∣ai​=aj​ for i=j}. Lk,nL_{k,n}Lk,n​ is the set of all kkk-tuples of distinct
elements of {1,…,n}\{1,\dots,n\}{1,…,n}.

What is ∣Lk,n∣|L_{k,n}|∣Lk,n​∣? Well, since the elements in the kkk-tuples are distinct,
there are nnn possibilities for the first one, n−1n-1n−1 possibilities for the
second one and so on. In general, for the jjj-th element in the tuple, there
n−(j−1)n-(j-1)n−(j−1) possibilities. Therefore, we get that ∣Lk,n∣=n(n−1)⋯(n−(k−1))|L_{k,n}| = n(n-1)\cdots (n-(k-1))∣Lk,n​∣=n(n−1)⋯(n−(k−1)).

Now, we shall analyse a relationship between Lk,nL_{k,n}Lk,n​ and Sk,nS_{k,n}Sk,n​ which will
allow us to compute ∣Sk,n∣|S_{k,n}|∣Sk,n​∣. Observe the following:

  • Each (a1,a2,…,ak)∈Lk,n(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_k) \in L_{k,n}(a1​,a2​,…,ak​)∈Lk,n​ can be mapped to an element
    {a1,…,ak}∈Sk,n\{a_1,\dots, a_k\} \in S_{k,n}{a1​,…,ak​}∈Sk,n​. This mapping removes the ordering from the
    kkk-tuple.
  • Each {a1,…,ak}∈Sk,n\{a_1,\dots, a_k\} \in S_{k,n}{a1​,…,ak​}∈Sk,n​ is then the image of k!k!k! different
    elements in Lk,nL_{k,n}Lk,n​.

Using these 2 observations, we may see the following:

∣Lk,n∣=∑Ω∈Sk,nk!=∣Sk,n∣⋅k!|L_{k,n}| = \sum_{\Omega \in S_{k,n}} k! = |S_{k,n}|\cdot k!∣Lk,n​∣=∑Ω∈Sk,n​​k!=∣Sk,n​∣⋅k!

  ⟹  ∣Sk,n∣=∣Lk,n∣k!\implies |S_{k,n}| = \frac{|L_{k,n}|}{k!}⟹∣Sk,n​∣=k!∣Lk,n​∣​, as desired.

Now, we may move forward to define the following object:

Binomial Coefficient: (nk):=n(n−1)⋯(n−k+1)k!\binom{n}{k} := \frac{n(n-1)\cdots(n - k + 1)}{k!}(kn​):=k!n(n−1)⋯(n−k+1)​
for 0≤k≤n0\leq k \leq n0≤k≤n. Note that by this defintion, it can also be seen that
(nk)=n!(n−k)!k!\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{(n-k)!k!}(kn​)=(n−k)!k!n!​. This version of the definition
immediately reveals the symmetrical nature of the binomial coeffcient:
(nk)=(nn−k)\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n}{n-k}(kn​)=(n−kn​) because of the commutativity of multiplication
in the denominator. For convenience and convention, we also define
(nk)=0\binom{n}{k} = 0(kn​)=0 for k>nk > nk>n.

Now, let Ak,n={(z1,…,zn)∈{0,1}n∣z1+⋯+zn=k}A_{k,n} = \{(z_1,\dots,z_n)\in \{0,1\}^n | z_1 + \dots + z_n = k\}Ak,n​={(z1​,…,zn​)∈{0,1}n∣z1​+⋯+zn​=k}
for 0≤k≤n0\leq k \leq n0≤k≤n. What is ∣Ak,n∣|A_{k,n}|∣Ak,n​∣? In previous proof, the size of
Sk,nS_{k,n}Sk,n​ was determined by analysing its relationship with Lk,nL_{k,n}Lk,n​ whose
size we could easily determine: we showed Lk,nL_{k,n}Lk,n​ is k!k!k! times larger than
Sk,nS_{k,n}Sk,n​, essentially proving a 1 to many mapping Sk,n↦Lk,nS_{k,n} \mapsto L_{k,n}Sk,n​↦Lk,n​.
This strategy can also be used to find ∣Ak,n∣|A_{k,n}|∣Ak,n​∣ with the only difference
being that this time, the relationship is 1-1 with a set of size
(nk)\binom{n}{k}(kn​). We conveniently already have such a set! - ∣Sk,n∣=(nk)|S_{k,n}| = \binom{n}{k}∣Sk,n​∣=(kn​), as previously shown.

THEOREM: ∣Ak,n∣=(nk)|A_{k,n}| = \binom{n}{k}∣Ak,n​∣=(kn​)

Proof: Observe the following:

  • Each (z1,…,zn)∈Ak,n(z_1,\dots, z_n) \in A_{k,n}(z1​,…,zn​)∈Ak,n​ has the propery that there must be kkk positions
    which where the element in the nnn-tuple is a 1. So each of these nnn-tuples can be mapped
    to a subset Ω={j∈{1,…,n}∣zj=1}∈Sk,n\Omega = \{j\in \{1,\dots,n\} | z_j = 1\} \in S_{k,n}Ω={j∈{1,…,n}∣zj​=1}∈Sk,n​.
  • Each subset Ω∈Sk,n\Omega \in S_{k,n}Ω∈Sk,n​ can be mapped to an element (z1,…,zk)∈Ak,n(z_1,\dots, z_k)\in A_{k,n}(z1​,…,zk​)∈Ak,n​
    where zj=1  ⟺  j∈Ωz_j = 1 \iff j\in \Omegazj​=1⟺j∈Ω

This shows a 1-1 mapping: for each set in Sk,nS_{k,n}Sk,n​, there is one corresponding nnn-tuple
in Ak,nA_{k,n}Ak,n​ and for every nnn-tuple in Ak,nA_{k,n}Ak,n​, there is one corresponding set in
Sk,nS_{k,n}Sk,n​. Therefore, ∣Sk,n∣=∣Ak,n∣|S_{k,n}| = |A_{k,n}|∣Sk,n​∣=∣Ak,n​∣, as desired.

THEOREM: Binomial Theorem: Let nnn be a non-negative integer. Then (1+x)n=∑k=0n(nk)xk(1 + x)^n = \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} x^k(1+x)n=∑k=0n​(kn​)xk.

Proof:

We can write 1+x=∑z∈{0,1}xz1 + x = \sum_{z\in\{0,1\}}x^z1+x=∑z∈{0,1}​xz. Using this, we can do the following:

(1+x)n=(∑z∈{0,1}xz)n=(∑z1∈{0,1}xz1)⋯(∑zn∈{0,1}xzn)=∑(z1,…,zn)∈{0,1}nxz1+⋯+zn\begin{aligned} (1 + x)^n &= (\sum_{z\in \{0,1\}} x^z)^n\\ &= (\sum_{z_1\in \{0,1\}} x^{z_1})\cdots (\sum_{z_n\in \{0,1\}} x^{z_n})\\ &= \sum_{(z_1,\dots, z_n)\in \{0,1\}^n} x^{z_1+\dots + z_n} \end{aligned}(1+x)n​=(z∈{0,1}∑​xz)n=(z1​∈{0,1}∑​xz1​)⋯(zn​∈{0,1}∑​xzn​)=(z1​,…,zn​)∈{0,1}n∑​xz1​+⋯+zn​​

At this point, what may help tie this problem up is the realisation that the set
{0,1}n=A0,n∪A1,n∪⋯∪An,n\{0,1\}^n = A_{0,n}\cup A_{1,n}\cup \dots \cup A_{n,n}{0,1}n=A0,n​∪A1,n​∪⋯∪An,n​, a disjoint union. This is
a useful decomposition because we already know about the size of An,kA_{n,k}An,k​. Then:

(1+x)n=∑(z1,…,zn)∈{0,1}nxz1+⋯+zn=∑k=0n(∑(z1,…,zn)∈Ak,nxz1+⋯+zn)=∑k=0n(∑(z1,…,zn)∈Ak,nxk)=∑k=0n∣Ak,n∣xk=∑k=0n(nk)xk\begin{aligned} (1 + x)^n &= \sum_{(z_1,\dots, z_n)\in \{0,1\}^n} x^{z_1+\dots + z_n}\\ &= \sum_{k=0}^n (\sum_{(z_1,\dots, z_n)\in A_{k,n}} x^{z_1+\dots + z_n})\\ &= \sum_{k=0}^n (\sum_{(z_1,\dots, z_n)\in A_{k,n}} x^k)\\ &= \sum_{k=0}^n |A_{k,n}| x^k\\ &= \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} x^k \end{aligned}(1+x)n​=(z1​,…,zn​)∈{0,1}n∑​xz1​+⋯+zn​=k=0∑n​((z1​,…,zn​)∈Ak,n​∑​xz1​+⋯+zn​)=k=0∑n​((z1​,…,zn​)∈Ak,n​∑​xk)=k=0∑n​∣Ak,n​∣xk=k=0∑n​(kn​)xk​

As desired.

Example: This binomial theorem can be useful when simplifying expressions. Here
is a simple example: Simplify ∑k=0n(nk)\sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k}∑k=0n​(kn​). At first glance, this looks
quite similar to the formula of the binomial theorem, just with xxx set to 1. Let's
use this observation:

∑k=1n(nk)xk=(1+x)n\sum_{k=1}^n \binom{n}{k} x^k = (1 + x)^n∑k=1n​(kn​)xk=(1+x)n

Setting x=1x = 1x=1:

∑k=1n(nk)=2n\sum_{k=1}^n \binom{n}{k} = 2^n∑k=1n​(kn​)=2n. And there we have it- a simplified expression.

Exercise: Show that ∑0≤j≤n2(n2j)=2n−1\sum_{0\leq j \leq \frac{n}{2}} \binom{n}{2j} = 2^{n-1}∑0≤j≤2n​​(2jn​)=2n−1.
Basically, that the sum of the binomial coefficient (nk)\binom{n}{k}(kn​) where kkk is even
is half of the sum of all of the terms. Again, we may use the binomial theorem here
to do most of the heavy lifting. Realise, first that

∑0≤j≤n2(n2j)=12(∑k=0n(nk)+∑k=0n(nk)(−1)k)\sum_{0\leq j\leq \frac{n}{2}} \binom{n}{2j} = \frac{1}{2}\left(\sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} + \sum_{k= 0}^n \binom{n}{k}(-1)^k\right)∑0≤j≤2n​​(2jn​)=21​(∑k=0n​(kn​)+∑k=0n​(kn​)(−1)k)

Here, the expression in question has been replaced as an average of 2 terms, both
derived from the binomial theorem. The second term in the RHS sum has the job of
cancelling out all of the odd terms in the sum from the first term. Then, since the
even terms will have been doubly added, the sum needs to be halved, making it an
average.

Next, note that the second term in the RHS sum is just the binomial theorem for
xxx set to −1-1−1, giving us (1+(−1))n=0(1+(-1))^n = 0(1+(−1))n=0. Therefore, we get:

∑0≤j≤n2(n2j)=12(2n+0)=122n=2n−1\begin{aligned} \sum_{0\leq j \leq \frac{n}{2}} \binom{n}{2j} &= \frac{1}{2}\left(2^n + 0 \right)\\ &= \frac{1}{2} 2^n\\ &= 2^{n-1} \end{aligned}0≤j≤2n​∑​(2jn​)​=21​(2n+0)=21​2n=2n−1​

As desired.

Pascal's Triangle: This is an object of interest in mathematics simply because of
the number of properties that emerge from it. It is formed by arranging the binomial
coefficients by nnn and kkk into a triangle.

===

One of the first things that one may notice is that every number in the triangle
is a sum of the 2 numbers above it. For example, 10 is the sum of 4 and 6 above it.
Therefore, it's easy to construct the triangle, row by row but more importantly,
this observation can be conjenctured as follows:

(nk)=?(n−1k−1)+(n−1k)\binom{n}{k} =? \binom{n-1}{k-1} + \binom{n-1}{k}(kn​)=?(k−1n−1​)+(kn−1​)

We'll prove this, and similar identities in the next section.

Combinatorial Proofs

  • Essentially, these are the kinds of proofs which rely on counting
  • A key method used is establishing identities by counting a set in two different
    ways.

Example: ∀1≤k≤n\forall 1\leq k \leq n∀1≤k≤n, (nk)=(n−1k−1)+(n−1k)\binom{n}{k} = \binom{n-1}{k-1} + \binom{n-1}{k}(kn​)=(k−1n−1​)+(kn−1​).
As conjenctured from Pascal's triangle above.

Proof: We want to approach the solution by counting a set in two different ways.
One way will give us the expression on the LHS and the other way will give us the
expression for the RHS. Since these expressions are representing the cardinality of
the same set, they must be equal.

Recall Sk,n={Ω∈{1,…,n}∣∣Ω∣=k}S_{k,n} = \{\Omega \in \{1,\dots,n\}||\Omega| = k\}Sk,n​={Ω∈{1,…,n}∣∣Ω∣=k} which has the property
that ∣Sk,n∣=(nk)|S_{k,n}| = \binom{n}{k}∣Sk,n​∣=(kn​). This gives us the RHS expression. Now, we need to
count the size of Sk,nS_{k,n}Sk,n​ in a different way which would give us the LHS expression.

Let A={Ω∈Sk,n∣n∈Ω}A=\{\Omega\in S_{k,n}| n\in \Omega\}A={Ω∈Sk,n​∣n∈Ω} and B={Ω∈Sk,n∣n∉Ω}B=\{\Omega\in S_{k,n}| n\notin \Omega\}B={Ω∈Sk,n​∣n∈/Ω}.
Clearly, A∩B=∅A\cap B = \emptysetA∩B=∅ and Sk,n=A∪BS_{k,n} = A\cup BSk,n​=A∪B which, by our findings in the
previous section, conventiently allows us to do ∣Sk,n∣=∣A∣+∣B∣|S_{k,n}| = |A| + |B|∣Sk,n​∣=∣A∣+∣B∣.

Case k=1k=1k=1: In this case, A={{n}}A=\{\{n\}\}A={{n}} and B={{1},…,{n−1}}B=\{\{1\},\dots, \{n-1\}\}B={{1},…,{n−1}}.
So that (n1)=∣S1,n∣=∣A∣+∣B∣=1+(n−1)=(n−10)+(n−11)\binom{n}{1} = |S_{1,n}| = |A| + |B| = 1 + (n-1) = \binom{n-1}{0} + \binom{n-1}{1}(1n​)=∣S1,n​∣=∣A∣+∣B∣=1+(n−1)=(0n−1​)+(1n−1​).

Case k>1k>1k>1: In this case, AAA and BBB can be viewed as follows:

A={{n}∪Q∣Q⊆{1,…,n} and ∣Q∣=k−1}={{n}∪Q∣Q∈Sk−1,n−1}\begin{aligned} A &= \{\{n\}\cup Q | Q \subseteq \{1,\dots, n\} \text{ and } |Q| = k-1\}\\ &= \{\{n\}\cup Q | Q\in S_{k-1, n-1}\} \end{aligned}A​={{n}∪Q∣Q⊆{1,…,n} and ∣Q∣=k−1}={{n}∪Q∣Q∈Sk−1,n−1​}​

B={Ω⊆{1,…,n−1}∣∣Ω∣=k}=Sk,n−1\begin{aligned} B &= \{\Omega\subseteq \{1,\dots, n-1\} | |\Omega| = k\}\\ &= S_{k,n-1} \end{aligned}B​={Ω⊆{1,…,n−1}∣∣Ω∣=k}=Sk,n−1​​

Using this representation, we see that

∣Sk,n∣=∣A∣+∣B∣=∣Sk−1,n−1∣+∣Sk,n−1∣=(n−1k−1)+(n−1k)\begin{aligned} |S_{k,n}| &= |A| + |B|\\ &= |S_{k-1,n-1}| + |S_{k,n-1}|\\ &= \binom{n-1}{k-1} + \binom{n-1}{k} \end{aligned}∣Sk,n​∣​=∣A∣+∣B∣=∣Sk−1,n−1​∣+∣Sk,n−1​∣=(k−1n−1​)+(kn−1​)​

As desired.

This identity can also be proven similarly using the set Ak,nA_{k,n}Ak,n​.

Example: (Hockey Stick Identity). This is one which also arises from Pascal's triangle.
In this case, for any number in Pascal's Triangle, the "hockey stick" of that number is the
set of numbers formed by moving one row up and to the left, then following the diagonal of
numbers from there to the right end of the triangle. This identity basically says that for
a number in Pascal's triangle, the sum of all other numbers in its "hockey stick" is itself.
Mathematically represented as:

(n+kn)=∑i=0k(n+i−1n−1)\binom{n+k}{n} = \sum_{i=0}^k \binom{n+i-1}{n-1}(nn+k​)=∑i=0k​(n−1n+i−1​) for n,k≥0n,k \geq 0n,k≥0.

We shall prove this by counting a set in two different ways. Take
Sn,n+k={Ω⊆{1,…,n+k}∣∣Ω∣=n}S_{n,n+k} = \{\Omega\subseteq \{1,\dots,n+k\}||\Omega| = n\}Sn,n+k​={Ω⊆{1,…,n+k}∣∣Ω∣=n}. So that ∣Sn,n+k∣=(n+kn)|S_{n,n+k}| = \binom{n+k}{n}∣Sn,n+k​∣=(nn+k​)
giving us the LHS of the identity. Now, we need to count Sn,n+kS_{n,n+k}Sn,n+k​ differently to get the
RHS.

To start, we can partition Sn,n+kS_{n,n+k}Sn,n+k​ as follows. Let
Wi={Ω∈Sn,n+k∣largest element of Wi is n+i}W_i = \{\Omega\in S_{n,n+k} | \text{largest element of }W_i\text{ is }n+i\}Wi​={Ω∈Sn,n+k​∣largest element of Wi​ is n+i} for 0≤i≤k0\leq i\leq k0≤i≤k.
So then we can represent Sn,n+k=W0∪⋯∪WkS_{n,n+k} = W_0\cup \dots \cup W_kSn,n+k​=W0​∪⋯∪Wk​, a disjoint union.
Before moving on, it is important to represent Wi={{n+i}∪Q∣Q∈Sn−1,n+i−1}W_i=\{\{n+i\}\cup Q| Q\in S_{n-1, n+i-1}\}Wi​={{n+i}∪Q∣Q∈Sn−1,n+i−1​}.

∣Sn,n+k∣=∑i=0k∣Wi∣=∑i=0k∣Sn−1,n+i−1∣=∑i=0k(n+i−1n−1)\begin{aligned} |S_{n,n+k}| &= \sum_{i=0}^k |W_i|\\ &= \sum_{i=0}^k |S_{n-1,n+i-1}|\\ &= \sum_{i=0}^k \binom{n+i-1}{n-1} \end{aligned}∣Sn,n+k​∣​=i=0∑k​∣Wi​∣=i=0∑k​∣Sn−1,n+i−1​∣=i=0∑k​(n−1n+i−1​)​

As desired.

Bijections

Bijections are important tools when it comes to combinatorial proof. They
enable one to show that two sets have the same size and do so conveniently.
Let us try to understand bijections. How does one know that two sets have
equal size?

Example: Let S={1,…,100}S=\{1,\dots,100\}S={1,…,100} be the set of integers between 1 and 100.
Let T={1,4,9,16,…,10000}T=\{1,4,9,16,\dots,10000\}T={1,4,9,16,…,10000} be the set of perfect squares between 1 and
10000.

In this example, clearly, these two sets have the same number of elements.
A pairing of 1 with 1, 2 with 4, 3 with 9, 4 with 16 and so on all the way
to 100 with 10000 should make this clear. There are no uncounted elements and
since there are 100 elements in SSS, the fact that they can be paired uniquely
with elements in TTT (with none being left unpaired from TTT or SSS) shows that
TTT has size 100 too. Let us formalize this notion:

Definition: A bijection is a mapping f:S↦Tf:S\mapsto Tf:S↦T satisfying:

  • ∀x1,x2∈S(f(x1)=f(x2))  ⟺  (x1=x2)\forall x_1,x_2\in S (f(x_1)=f(x_2)) \iff (x_1 = x_2)∀x1​,x2​∈S(f(x1​)=f(x2​))⟺(x1​=x2​)

This says that "For all x1,x2x_1,x_2x1​,x2​ in SSS, f(x1)=f(x2)f(x_1)=f(x_2)f(x1​)=f(x2​) if and only if
x1=x2x_1=x_2x1​=x2​". A function satisfying this property is said to be one-to-one.
This is because every element of SSS maps to a unique element in TTT under
the action of fff.

  • ∀y∈T(∃x∈S[f(x)=y])\forall y\in T (\exists x\in S [f(x) = y])∀y∈T(∃x∈S[f(x)=y])

This says that "For every yyy in TTT, there exists an xxx in SSS which
satisfies f(x)=yf(x) = yf(x)=y. A function satisfying this property is said to be onto.
This is because the image of SSS under the action of fff is the whole of TTT
i.e. every element in TTT can be obtained as a result of the action of fff on
some value in SSS.

To test that a function is a bijection, it is sufficient to show that it is
both one-to-one and onto as stated in the above 2 bullets.

Example (Cont'd.): We can now formalize the pairing that was discussed in
the example above. Define a function f:S↦Tf:S\mapsto Tf:S↦T like so: ∀x∈S\forall x\in S∀x∈S,
we have that f(x)=x2f(x)=x^2f(x)=x2. Let us show that this function satisfies the above two
properties to be called a bijection.

  • Verify one-to-one: If we have x1,x2∈Sx_1,x_2\in Sx1​,x2​∈S such that f(x1)=f(x2)f(x_1) = f(x_2)f(x1​)=f(x2​).
    This would mean that x12=x22x_1^2 = x_2^2x12​=x22​. But since both x1,x2x_1,x_2x1​,x2​ are members of
    SSS, they must be positive. So taking the square root leaves us with
    x1=x2x_1 = x_2x1​=x2​. Therefore, fff is one-to-one.

  • Verify onto: If we have y∈Ty\in Ty∈T, then by definition, it is a perfect
    square between 1 and 10000 therefore, its square root must lie between 1 and
    100, which are the members of SSS. Therefore, we can take x=y∈Sx=\sqrt{y}\in Sx=y​∈S
    and then we get that f(x)=(x)2=yf(x) = (\sqrt{x})^2 = yf(x)=(x​)2=y. This shows that fff is onto.

Therefore, the function fff is a bijection. We still have to prove that this
bijection actually gives us the result that the sets SSS and TTT have the same
size.

THEOREM: Suppose S,TS,TS,T are two finite sets and f:S↦Tf:S\mapsto Tf:S↦T. Then:

  • If fff is one-to-one, then ∣S∣≤∣T∣|S| \leq |T|∣S∣≤∣T∣
  • If fff is onto, then ∣S∣≥∣T∣|S| \geq |T|∣S∣≥∣T∣
  • If fff is a bijection, then ∣S∣=∣T∣|S| = |T|∣S∣=∣T∣

Proof:

  1. Suppose that fff is one-to-one. This means that every element of SSS maps
    to a unique element in TTT under the action of fff. Therefore, there must be
    at least ∣S∣|S|∣S∣ elements in ∣T∣|T|∣T∣ i.e. ∣S∣≤∣T∣|S| \leq |T|∣S∣≤∣T∣.
  2. Suppose that fff is onto. Then, every element in TTT is the image of some
    element in SSS. Therefore, by the definition of a function (that an input
    will always produce the same output), this allows us to see that the size of
    SSS is at least the size of TTT i.e. ∣S∣≥∣T∣|S| \geq |T|∣S∣≥∣T∣.
  3. If fff is a bijection, it is both one-to-one and onto. Therefore, we see
    that it must be the case that (∣S∣≤∣T∣)∧(∣S∣≥∣T∣)(|S| \leq |T|)\land (|S| \geq |T|)(∣S∣≤∣T∣)∧(∣S∣≥∣T∣), which
    leaves us with one option: ∣S∣=∣T∣|S| = |T|∣S∣=∣T∣.

As desired.

There is another method for showing that a function is a bijection. This one
relies on the inverse of a function, which comes sort of naturally when
speaking of bijective maps- you need a way to reverse the action of the
function. Inverse functions will capture this idea and provide yet another
tool for combinatorial proofs.

Inverse Functions

Definition An inverse of a function f:S↦Tf:S\mapsto Tf:S↦T is a function
f−1:T↦Sf^{-1}: T \mapsto Sf−1:T↦S which satisfies the following properties:

  • ∀x∈S(f−1(f(x))=x)\forall x\in S (f^{-1}(f(x)) = x)∀x∈S(f−1(f(x))=x).
    This says that for every element in SSS, the action of fff on xxx can be
    undone through the action of f−1f^{-1}f−1.
  • ∀y∈T(f(f−1(y))=y)\forall y\in T (f(f^{-1}(y)) = y)∀y∈T(f(f−1(y))=y).
    This says that for every element in TTT, the action of f−1f^{-1}f−1 can be
    undone through the action of fff.

This definition can be used to verify that a function is an inverse function.
Now, let us the utility of inverse functions through this theorem:

THEOREM: A function f:S↦Tf:S\mapsto Tf:S↦T has an inverse function if and only if
it is a bijection.

Proof: (Forwards) Assume that fff has an inverse function
f−1:T↦Sf^{-1}:T\mapsto Sf−1:T↦S. We need to show that fff is a bijection.

  • (Proving that fff is one-to-one) Take x1,x2∈Sx_1,x_2\in Sx1​,x2​∈S such that
    f(x1)=f(x2)f(x_1)=f(x_2)f(x1​)=f(x2​). Since f−1f^{-1}f−1 is the inverse of fff, it reverses the
    action of fff, so we get

f−1(f(x1))=f−1(f(x2))  ⟹  x1=x2f^{-1}(f(x_1)) = f^{-1}(f(x_2)) \implies x_1 = x_2f−1(f(x1​))=f−1(f(x2​))⟹x1​=x2​

This shows that fff is one-to-one.

  • (Proving that fff is onto) Pick a y∈Ty\in Ty∈T. We need to find a value
    x∈Sx\in Sx∈S such that f(x)=yf(x) = yf(x)=y. Well, take x=f−1(y)x = f^{-1}(y)x=f−1(y) and then:

f(x)=f(f−1(y))=yf(x) = f(f^{-1}(y)) = yf(x)=f(f−1(y))=y

This shows that fff is onto and, together with the above, that fff is a
bijection.

(Backwards) Now, let us assume that fff is a bijection. Need to show that
fff has an inverse function.

We can construct one as follows: given a y∈Ty\in Ty∈T, we can find an x∈Sx\in Sx∈S
such that f(x)=yf(x)=yf(x)=y. This is possible because the assumption of bijection
means that fff is onto. Keeping this in mind, we make the following definition:

Let f−1:T↦Sf^{-1}:T\mapsto Sf−1:T↦S be defined for all y∈Ty\in Ty∈T, f−1(y)=xf^{-1}(y) = xf−1(y)=x as stated
in the passage above. To prove that f−1f^{-1}f−1 is an inverse:

  • Pick an x∈Sx\in Sx∈S. Say y=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x). Then: f−1(y)=f−1(f(x))=xf^{-1}(y) = f^{-1}(f(x)) = xf−1(y)=f−1(f(x))=x.
    We see that f−1f^{-1}f−1 reverses the action of fff.
  • Now pick a y∈Ty\in Ty∈T. Say x=f−1(y)x=f^{-1}(y)x=f−1(y). Then: f(x)=f(f−1(y))=yf(x) = f(f^{-1}(y)) = yf(x)=f(f−1(y))=y

This completes the proof of the backwards direction and finally proves the
theorem above.

Generating Series

Context: Let SSS be a set. We define a "weight" function as a function
w:S↦{0,1,2,3,… }w:S\mapsto \{0,1,2,3,\dots\}w:S↦{0,1,2,3,…}.

Question: How many δ∈S\delta \in Sδ∈S such that w(δ)=kw(\delta) = kw(δ)=k?

Examples:

  1. With S={a,b,c}S=\{a,b,c\}S={a,b,c} and w:S↦{0,1,2,3,… }w:S\mapsto \{0,1,2,3,\dots\}w:S↦{0,1,2,3,…} defined by: w(a)=1w(a) = 1w(a)=1,
    w(b)=1w(b) = 1w(b)=1, w(c)=2w(c) = 2w(c)=2. There are two elements of SSS with weight 1 and one
    element with weight 222. This is the kind of information that we wish to
    capture.
  2. If S={Ω⊆{0,1,2,…,n}∣w(Ω)=∣Ω∣}S=\{\Omega\subseteq \{0,1,2,\dots, n\}| w(\Omega) = |\Omega|\}S={Ω⊆{0,1,2,…,n}∣w(Ω)=∣Ω∣} (SSS is the
    set of subsets of {1,2,…,n}\{1,2,\dots,n\}{1,2,…,n} with the weight of a subset being defined
    as the size of the subset). The number of elements with weight kkk is easily
    obtained (from our previous work with Sk,nS_{k,n}Sk,n​) as (nk)\binom{n}{k}(kn​).

Definition: A generating function for a set SSS with respect to a
weight function w:S↦{0,1,2,… }w:S\mapsto \{0,1,2,\dots\}w:S↦{0,1,2,…} encodes information regarding the
counts of elements in SSS with the weights {0,1,2,… }\{0,1,2,\dots\}{0,1,2,…}. It is denoted by
ΦS(x)\Phi_{S}(x)ΦS​(x) and is defined as

ΦS(x)=∑δ∈Sxw(δ)\Phi_{S}(x) = \sum_{\delta \in S} x^{w(\delta)}ΦS​(x)=∑δ∈S​xw(δ)

When one stares at this definition long enough, one realises that it is a way
of keeping track of the set of weights that occur in SSS, with respect to the
weight function www.

We can manipulate the above definition to make this clearer:

ΦS(x)=∑δ∈Sxw(δ)=∑k≥0(∑(δ∈S)∧(w(δ)=k))xk=∑k≥0akxk\begin{aligned} \Phi_{S}(x) &= \sum_{\delta \in S} x^{w(\delta)}\\ &= \sum_{k\geq 0}\left( \sum_{(\delta \in S) \land (w(\delta) = k)} \right) x^k\\ &= \sum_{k\geq 0} a_k x^k \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)​=δ∈S∑​xw(δ)=k≥0∑​⎝⎛​(δ∈S)∧(w(δ)=k)∑​⎠⎞​xk=k≥0∑​ak​xk​

Where ak=∣{δ∈S∣w(δ)=k}∣a_k = |\{\delta \in S | w(\delta) = k\}|ak​=∣{δ∈S∣w(δ)=k}∣.

The coefficient of the xnx^nxn term tells us the number of elements in the set
SSS which have the weight nnn (of course, with respect to the weight function
that was used to compute the series).

Examples:

  1. What is the generating series of the corresponding example 1 above?
    We compute: ΦS(x)=xw(a)+xw(b)+xw(c)=x1+x1+x2=2x+x2\Phi_S(x) = x^{w(a)} + x^{w(b)} + x^{w(c)} = x^1+x^1+x^2 = 2x + x^2ΦS​(x)=xw(a)+xw(b)+xw(c)=x1+x1+x2=2x+x2. Note how even if the weight function were defined differently
    (like w(a)=w(c)=1w(a) = w(c) = 1w(a)=w(c)=1 and w(b)=2w(b) = 2w(b)=2). The resulting generating series
    is the same. What this means is that there is information about the weights
    of elements of SSS that is not preserved.
  2. For corresponding example 2 above, we have the generating function

ΦS(x)=∑k≥0∣{Ω∈S∣w(Ω)=k}∣⋅xk=∑k≥0(nk)xk=∑k=0n(nk)xk=(1+x)n\begin{aligned} \Phi_S(x) &= \sum_{k\geq 0} |\{\Omega \in S | w(\Omega) = k\}|\cdot x^k\\ &= \sum_{k\geq 0} \binom{n}{k}x^k\\ &= \sum_{k=0}^n \binom{n}{k} x^k\\ &= (1+x)^n \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)​=k≥0∑​∣{Ω∈S∣w(Ω)=k}∣⋅xk=k≥0∑​(kn​)xk=k=0∑n​(kn​)xk=(1+x)n​

This may all be nice, but what is the point of encoding this information in a
generating series?

Theorem: Suppose that SSS is a finite set with the weight funtion
w:S↦{0,1,2,… }w:S \mapsto \{0,1,2,\dots\}w:S↦{0,1,2,…}. Let ΦS\Phi_SΦS​ be the generating series for SSS
with respect to www. Then:

  1. ∣S∣=ΦS(1)|S| = \Phi_S(1)∣S∣=ΦS​(1). This says that the size of the set SSS is equal to its
    generating series evaluated at x=1x=1x=1.
  2. ∑δ∈Sw(δ)=dΦsdx∣x=1\sum_{\delta \in S} w(\delta) = \left.\frac{d\Phi_s}{dx}\right|_{x=1}∑δ∈S​w(δ)=dxdΦs​​∣∣​x=1​.
    This says that the sum of the weights of the elements in SSS is exactly
    equal to the first derivative of the generating series, evaluated at x=1x=1x=1.

Let's see why this works:

Proof:

  1. Here is a short proof for statement 1 above

ΦS(1)=∑δ∈Sxw(δ)∣x=1=∑δ∈S1w(δ)=∑δ∈S1=∣S∣\begin{aligned} \Phi_S(1) &= \left.\sum_{\delta \in S} x^{w(\delta)}\right|_{x=1}\\ &= \sum_{\delta\in S} 1^{w(\delta)} = \sum_{\delta \in S} 1 \\ &= |S| \end{aligned}ΦS​(1)​=δ∈S∑​xw(δ)∣∣​x=1​=δ∈S∑​1w(δ)=δ∈S∑​1=∣S∣​
2. Similarly, here is a short proof for statement 2

dΦSdx∣x=1=∑δ∈Sw(δ)xw(δ)−1∣x=1=∑δ∈Sw(δ)1w(δ)−1=∑δ∈Sw(δ)\begin{aligned} \left.\frac{d\Phi_S}{dx}\right|_{x=1} &= \left.\sum_{\delta \in S} w(\delta) x^{w(\delta) - 1}\right|_{x=1}\\ &= \sum_{\delta \in S} w(\delta) 1^{w(\delta) - 1}\\ &= \sum_{\delta \in S} w(\delta)\\ \end{aligned}dxdΦS​​∣∣​x=1​​=δ∈S∑​w(δ)xw(δ)−1∣∣​x=1​=δ∈S∑​w(δ)1w(δ)−1=δ∈S∑​w(δ)​

Example: Consider a sequence of nnn coin flips and suppose you win $1 with
each time that you get heads after tails or tails after heads. Compute the
expected winnings using generating series.

The above theorem allows us to get the sum of the weights of the elements in
SSS as the number of elements. Putting these together, we can get the average
weight of an element in SSS. Contextualizing to this example, we can benefit by
defining a weight function in terms of the rewards and then compute the average
as explained to get the expected winnings. Take a moment to contemplate how
you would solve this before moving on...

We need to get a 'mathematical handle' on the occurrence of tails after heads
and heads after tails. So, for a sequence of nnn coin flips, we can concoct
n−1n-1n−1 binary variables indicating whether the next flip in the sequence differs
from the current one:

∀i∈[1,n−1]\forall i\in [1,n-1]∀i∈[1,n−1] define zi={1,if (i+1)th outcome is different from ith0,otherwisez_i = \left\{\begin{array}{lr} 1, & \text{if }(i+1)\text{th outcome is different from }i\text{th}\\ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{array}\right.zi​={1,0,​if (i+1)th outcome is different from ithotherwise​

Using this string of binary variables z1,z2,…,zn−1z_1,z_2,\dots,z_{n-1}z1​,z2​,…,zn−1​, one can derive
useful information about the sequence of nnn coin flips. We can put this all in
a set S={(z1,z2,…zn−1)∣zj∈{0,1}}S=\{(z_1, z_2, \dots z_{n-1}) | z_j\in \{0,1\}\}S={(z1​,z2​,…zn−1​)∣zj​∈{0,1}} with the weight
function defined by w((z1,…,zn−1))=∑i=1n−1ziw((z_1,\dots,z_{n-1})) = \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} z_iw((z1​,…,zn−1​))=∑i=1n−1​zi​.

We can now view S={0,1}n−1S = \{0,1\}^{n-1}S={0,1}n−1 and the weight function is essentially
computing the number of ones in an entry from SSS- each of which corresponds
to a dollar reward (as per the rules of the game). Then we can compute
ΦS(x)=∑i≥0aixi\Phi_S(x) = \sum_{i\geq 0} a_i x^{i}ΦS​(x)=∑i≥0​ai​xi, where aia_iai​ is the number of elements
in SSS which have weight iii. Fortunatly, we have alredy done this (see work on
Ak,nA_{k,n}Ak,n​)- we know that ai=(n−1i)a_i = \binom{n-1}{i}ai​=(in−1​). Therefore, we finally get
ΦS(x)=(1+x)n−1\Phi_S(x) = (1+x)^{n-1}ΦS​(x)=(1+x)n−1, by the binomial theorem.

Now, we use the theorem above:

∣S∣=ΦS(1)=2n−1|S| = \Phi_S(1) = 2^{n-1}∣S∣=ΦS​(1)=2n−1

∑δ∈Sw(δ)=dΦSdx∣x=1=(n−1)(1+x)n−2∣x=1=(n−1)2n−2\begin{aligned} \sum_{\delta \in S} w(\delta) &= \left.\frac{d\Phi_S}{dx}\right|_{x=1}\\ &= \left.(n-1)(1+x)^{n-2}\right|_{x=1}\\ &= (n-1)2^{n-2} \end{aligned}δ∈S∑​w(δ)​=dxdΦS​​∣∣​x=1​=(n−1)(1+x)n−2∣∣​x=1​=(n−1)2n−2​

We can readily compute the expected winnings now:

Expected winnings=dΦSdx∣x=1∣S∣=(n−1)2n−22n−1\begin{aligned} \text{Expected winnings} &= \frac{\left.\frac{d\Phi_S}{dx}\right|_{x=1}}{|S|}\\ &= \frac{(n-1)2^{n-2}}{2^{n-1}}\\ \end{aligned}Expected winnings​=∣S∣dxdΦS​​∣∣​x=1​​=2n−1(n−1)2n−2​​

So far, we have only been considering the cases in which the set SSS is finite.
What happens to ΦS\Phi_SΦS​ when SSS is an infinite set? In this case, we have to
make the following distinction:

  • If SSS is finite, then ΦS(x)\Phi_S(x)ΦS​(x) is a polynomial
  • If SSS is infinite, then ΦS(s)\Phi_S(s)ΦS​(s) is a formal power series (given that
    the coefficients aka_kak​ are finite)

At this point, we introduce the concept of formal power series through which
we shall obtain tools to deal with generating series.

Formal Power Series

A formal power series is an expression c0+c1x1+c2x2+…c_0 + c_1x^1 + c_2x^2 + \dotsc0​+c1​x1+c2​x2+… where
(c0,c1,c2,… )(c_0, c_1, c_2, \dots)(c0​,c1​,c2​,…) is a sequence of rational numbers (for our intents
and purposes, the coefficients are rational numbers, but the important part is
that they are finite). This is to concretize the notion of a generating series
as a formal power series, and to then to apply the properties of formal power
series in the realm of generating series.

Let C(x)C(x)C(x) be a formal power series (to be abbreviated as f.p.s). We can write
C(x)=∑i=0∞cixiC(x) = \sum_{i=0}^\infty c_i x^iC(x)=∑i=0∞​ci​xi and define [xn]=cn[x^n] = c_n[xn]=cn​. So if
C(x)=∑i=0∞2ixiC(x) = \sum_{i=0}^\infty 2^i x^iC(x)=∑i=0∞​2ixi, then [x0]C(x)=1[x^0]C(x) = 1[x0]C(x)=1, [x1]C(x)=2[x^1]C(x) = 2[x1]C(x)=2,
[x2]C(x)=4[x^2]C(x) = 4[x2]C(x)=4 and so on. Let us now consider the operations which can be
performed with formal power series.

Operations on Formal Power Series

Consider two formal power series A(x)=∑i=0∞aixiA(x) = \sum_{i=0}^\infty a_i x^iA(x)=∑i=0∞​ai​xi and
B(x)=∑i=0∞bixiB(x) = \sum_{i=0}^\infty b_i x^iB(x)=∑i=0∞​bi​xi.

EQUALITY: ((A(x)=B(x))  ⟺  (∀k∈N(ak=bk)))((A(x) = B(x)) \iff (\forall k \in \mathbb{N} (a_k = b_k)))((A(x)=B(x))⟺(∀k∈N(ak​=bk​))).
This states that two formal power series are considered to be equal if and only
if the coefficients aka_kak​ and bkb_kbk​ are the same for all natural number kkk.

ADDITION: A(x)+B(x)=∑k=0∞(ak+bk)xkA(x) + B(x) = \sum_{k=0}^\infty (a_k+b_k)x^kA(x)+B(x)=∑k=0∞​(ak​+bk​)xk. This is a valid
definition for addition since the resulting series is also a f.p.s- the
coefficients (ak+bk)(a_k+b_k)(ak​+bk​) are all finite rational numbers (by the declaration
that AAA and BBB are formal power series above).

MULTIPLICATION: Defined as follows:

A(x)B(x)=∑j=0∞∑k=0∞ajbkxj+k=∑n=0∞(∑j=0najbn−j)xn\begin{aligned} A(x)B(x) &= \sum_{j=0}^\infty \sum_{k=0}^\infty a_jb_k x^{j+k}\\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \left( \sum_{j=0}^n a_j b_{n-j} \right)x^n\\ \end{aligned}A(x)B(x)​=j=0∑∞​k=0∑∞​aj​bk​xj+k=n=0∑∞​(j=0∑n​aj​bn−j​)xn​

Note that we can identify the term [xn]A(x)B(x)=∑j=0najbn−j[x^n]A(x)B(x) = \sum_{j=0}^n a_j b_{n-j}[xn]A(x)B(x)=∑j=0n​aj​bn−j​
from the last expression above. This term is also a rational number since it
is a finite sum of product of pairs of rational numbers.

Example: Let A(x)=(1+x)mA(x) = (1+x)^mA(x)=(1+x)m and B(x)=∑k=0m2kxkB(x) = \sum_{k=0}^m 2^k x^kB(x)=∑k=0m​2kxk. Let us
compute [xn]A(x)B(x)[x^n]A(x)B(x)[xn]A(x)B(x).

We know, from the binomial theorem that A(x)=∑j=0m(mj)xjA(x) = \sum_{j=0}^m \binom{m}{j}x^jA(x)=∑j=0m​(jm​)xj.
So [xn]A(x)=(mj)[x^n]A(x) = \binom{m}{j}[xn]A(x)=(jm​).
It is also clear from the summand of B(x)B(x)B(x) that [xn]B(x)=2n[x^n]B(x)=2^n[xn]B(x)=2n. Putting these
two together:

[xn]A(x)B(x)=∑i=0n[xi]A(x)[xn−i]B(x)=∑i=0n(mi)2n−i=2n∑i=0n(mi)2−i\begin{aligned} [x^n]A(x)B(x) &= \sum_{i=0}^n [x^i]A(x)[x^{n-i}]B(x) \\ &= \sum_{i=0}^n \binom{m}{i}2^{n-i} \\ &= 2^n \sum_{i=0}^n \binom{m}{i}2^{-i} \\ \end{aligned}[xn]A(x)B(x)​=i=0∑n​[xi]A(x)[xn−i]B(x)=i=0∑n​(im​)2n−i=2ni=0∑n​(im​)2−i​

Now, notice what happens when n>mn>mn>m- the term (mi)\binom{m}{i}(im​) will be zero for values
of i>mi>mi>m sum would effiectively run from 1 to mmm.

2n∑i=0m(mi)2−i=2n∑i=0m(mi)(12)i=2n(1+12)m=2n−m3m\begin{aligned} 2^n\sum_{i=0}^m \binom{m}{i} 2^{-i} &= 2^n\sum_{i=0}^m \binom{m}{i} \left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^i\\ &= 2^n \left( 1+\frac{1}{2} \right)^m\\ &= 2^{n-m}3^m \end{aligned}2ni=0∑m​(im​)2−i​=2ni=0∑m​(im​)(21​)i=2n(1+21​)m=2n−m3m​

So we have that [xn]A(x)B(x)=2n−m3m[x^n]A(x)B(x)=2^{n-m}3^m[xn]A(x)B(x)=2n−m3m.

Example (Multiplicative Shift): This example illustrates how for all k,n≥0k,n\geq 0k,n≥0,
the term [xn]xkA(x)[x^n]x^k A(x)[xn]xkA(x), is similar to a shift in indices. Let
A(x)=∑j≥0ajxjA(x)=\sum_{j\geq 0}a_j x^jA(x)=∑j≥0​aj​xj.

[xn]xkA(x)=[xn]xk(∑j≥0ajxj)=[xn]∑j=0∞ajxj+k  , let l=k+j=[xn]∑l=k∞al−kxl={an−k  , if n−k≥00  , if n−k<0\begin{aligned} [x^n] x^k A(x) &= [x^n] x^k \left( \sum_{j\geq 0} a_j x^j \right)\\ &= [x^n] \sum_{j= 0}^\infty a_j x^{j+k} \;\text{, let }l = k + j\\ &= [x^n] \sum_{l=k}^\infty a_{l-k} x^l\\ &= \begin{cases} a_{n-k} &\;\text{, if }n-k\geq 0\\ 0 &\;\text{, if }n-k <0 \end{cases} \end{aligned}[xn]xkA(x)​=[xn]xk(j≥0∑​aj​xj)=[xn]j=0∑∞​aj​xj+k, let l=k+j=[xn]l=k∑∞​al−k​xl={an−k​0​, if n−k≥0, if n−k<0​​

This is a rule/identity that will be used time and time again.

Definition (Formal Power Series Inverses): Let A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x) be formal power
series satisfying A(x)B(x)=1A(x)B(x)=1A(x)B(x)=1, then one says that B(x)B(x)B(x) is the inverse of
A(x)A(x)A(x) and writes B(x)=A(x)−1B(x)=A(x)^{-1}B(x)=A(x)−1 or B(x)=1A(x)B(x)=\frac{1}{A(x)}B(x)=A(x)1​.

Example: Let A(x)=1−xA(x)=1-xA(x)=1−x, B(x)=∑i=≥0xkB(x)=\sum_{i=\geq 0} x^kB(x)=∑i=≥0​xk.

We can write A(x)A(x)A(x), using the binomial theorem, as
A(x)=(1−x)1=∑k=01(1k)(−x)kA(x)=(1-x)^1=\sum_{k=0}^1 \binom{1}{k} (-x)^kA(x)=(1−x)1=∑k=01​(k1​)(−x)k. Using this, it can be seen that
[xn]A(x)=(−1)n(1n)[x^n]A(x) = (-1)^n\binom{1}{n}[xn]A(x)=(−1)n(n1​) and this forms the sequence
(1,−1,0,0,0,… )(1,-1,0,0,0,\dots)(1,−1,0,0,0,…).

Now, using the multiplication rule:

an=[xn]A(x)B(x)=∑j=0n[xj]A(x)[xn−j]B(x)=∑j=0n(−1)j(1j)(1)={0 if n≥01 if n=0\begin{aligned} a_n = [x^n]A(x)B(x) &= \sum_{j = 0}^n [x^j]A(x) [x^{n-j}]B(x)\\ &= \sum_{j = 0}^n (-1)^j\binom{1}{j} (1)\\ &= \begin{cases} 0 &\text{ if }n\geq 0\\ 1 &\text{ if }n=0 \end{cases} \end{aligned}an​=[xn]A(x)B(x)​=j=0∑n​[xj]A(x)[xn−j]B(x)=j=0∑n​(−1)j(j1​)(1)={01​ if n≥0 if n=0​​

The only term with non-zero coefficent in A(x)B(x)A(x)B(x)A(x)B(x) is the x0x^0x0 term (the
constant term), which has coefficent 1. Therfore, we see that A(x)B(x)=1A(x)B(x) =1A(x)B(x)=1
ans as such we can write ∑i=0∞xi=11−x\sum_{i=0}^\infty x^i = \frac{1}{1-x}∑i=0∞​xi=1−x1​, using the
notation in the definiton of inverses in formal power series.

Theorem (Negative Binomial Series): As an extension of the example above,
we have the following theorem: for all k=1,2,3,…k=1,2,3,\dotsk=1,2,3,… we have that

1(1−x)k=∑n=0∞(n+k−1k−1)xn\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{(1-x)^k} &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \binom{n+k-1}{k-1} x^n \end{aligned}(1−x)k1​​=n=0∑∞​(k−1n+k−1​)xn​

Proof: The proof of this theorem is provided using induction on kkk.

In the base case when k=1k=1k=1, we check:

[xn]1(1−x)1=[xn]∑j=0∞(j+1−11−1)xj[xn]11−x=[xn]∑j=0∞(j0)xj[xn]∑i=0∞xi=[xn]∑j=0∞xj1=1\begin{aligned} [x^n]\frac{1}{(1-x)^1} &= [x^n]\sum_{j=0}^\infty \binom{j+1-1}{1-1} x^j\\ [x^n]\frac{1}{1-x} &= [x^n]\sum_{j=0}^\infty \binom{j}{0} x^j\\ [x^n]\sum_{i=0}^\infty x^i &= [x^n]\sum_{j=0}^\infty x^j\\ 1 &= 1 \end{aligned}[xn](1−x)11​[xn]1−x1​[xn]i=0∑∞​xi1​=[xn]j=0∑∞​(1−1j+1−1​)xj=[xn]j=0∑∞​(0j​)xj=[xn]j=0∑∞​xj=1​

The base case holds. Now, onto the inductive step where it is assumed that
the theorem holds for some kkk. Now, to show that it holds for k+1k+1k+1.

1(1−x)k+1=1(1−x)k1(1−x)=(∑n=0∞(n+k−1k−1)xn)⋅(∑i=0∞xi)\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{(1-x)^{k+1}} &= \frac{1}{(1-x)^k} \frac{1}{(1-x)}\\ &= \left( \sum_{n=0}^\infty \binom{n+k-1}{k-1} x^n \right)\cdot \left( \sum_{i=0}^\infty x^i \right) \end{aligned}(1−x)k+11​​=(1−x)k1​(1−x)1​=(n=0∑∞​(k−1n+k−1​)xn)⋅(i=0∑∞​xi)​

Now that we have 1(1−x)k+1\frac{1}{(1-x)^{k+1}}(1−x)k+11​ expressed as a product of two power
series, we can use the multiplication rule to compute the coefficient for the
xnx^nxn term.

[xn]1(1−x)k+1=[xn](∑j=0∞(j+k−1k−1)xj)⋅(∑i=0∞xi)=∑j=0n(j+k−1k−1)   by the Multiplication Rule=(n+kk)   by the Hockey Stick Identity\begin{aligned} [x^n]\frac{1}{(1-x)^{k+1}} &= [x^n]\left( \sum_{j=0}^\infty \binom{j+k-1}{k-1} x^j \right)\cdot \left( \sum_{i=0}^\infty x^i \right)\\ &= \sum_{j=0}^n \binom{j+k-1}{k-1} \;\text{ by the Multiplication Rule}\\ &= \binom{n+k}{k} \;\text{ by the Hockey Stick Identity} \end{aligned}[xn](1−x)k+11​​=[xn](j=0∑∞​(k−1j+k−1​)xj)⋅(i=0∑∞​xi)=j=0∑n​(k−1j+k−1​) by the Multiplication Rule=(kn+k​) by the Hockey Stick Identity​

The inductive step holds too and therefore so does the theorem for all
k=1,2,…k=1,2,\dotsk=1,2,…. This completes the proof. ■\blacksquare■

This theorem is also an important one and should be familiarized with as it
can help with quick conversions to and from power series.

NOTE: There are conditions under which formal power series have inverses.
Here's an example highlighting a case when the f.p.s. has no inverse. Consider
A(x)=xA(x)=xA(x)=x, which is claimed to have no inverse. Let us proove this.

The proof provided here is by contradiction. Suppose A(x)A(x)A(x) did have an inverse.
Then, there would exist another f.p.s. B(x)=∑i≥0bixiB(x)=\sum_{i\geq 0}b_i x^iB(x)=∑i≥0​bi​xi such that
A(x)B(x)=xB(x)=1A(x)B(x)=xB(x)=1A(x)B(x)=xB(x)=1. This looks like a good place to use the "Multiplicative
shift" mentioned before to get:

[xn]A(x)B(x)=[xn]xB(x)={bn−1   if n≥00   if n=0\begin{aligned} [x^n]A(x)B(x) &= [x^n]xB(x)\\ &= \begin{cases} b_{n-1} &\;\text{ if }n\geq 0\\ 0 &\;\text{ if }n=0 \end{cases} \end{aligned}[xn]A(x)B(x)​=[xn]xB(x)={bn−1​0​ if n≥0 if n=0​​

Note that if B(x)B(x)B(x) is an inverse for A(x)A(x)A(x), then [x0]A(x)B(x)=1[x^0]A(x)B(x)=1[x0]A(x)B(x)=1, but with
the result above, we see that [x0]A(x)B(x)=0[x^0]A(x)B(x)=0[x0]A(x)B(x)=0, which is a contradiction.
The starting assumption, that A(x)A(x)A(x) has an inverse must have been wrong then.
Therefore, A(x)=xA(x)=xA(x)=x has no inverse.

Theorem (Condition for Inverses): An f.p.s. A(x)A(x)A(x) has an inverse iff
[x0]A(x)≠0[x^0]A(x)\neq 0[x0]A(x)=0.

Proof: [Forwards] First, assume that [x0]A(x)=an=0[x^0]A(x)=a_n=0[x0]A(x)=an​=0. Now, we need to show
that A(x)A(x)A(x) has no inverse (This is proving the contrapositive which is
logically equivalent).

Say B(x)B(x)B(x) is another f.p.s. with [x0]B(x)=b0[x^0]B(x)=b_0[x0]B(x)=b0​.
Let us check [x0]A(x)B(x)=a0b0=0[x^0]A(x)B(x) = a_0b_0 = 0[x0]A(x)B(x)=a0​b0​=0 since a0=0a_0 = 0a0​=0. This means that
A(x)B(x)A(x)B(x)A(x)B(x) can never be equal to 111, no matter the f.p.s. B(x)B(x)B(x).
Therefore, A(x)A(x)A(x) has no inverse. This proves that if A(x)A(x)A(x) has an inverse
then a0≠0a_0\neq 0a0​=0.

[Backwards] Now, suppose that [x0]A(x)≠0[x^0]A(x)\neq 0[x0]A(x)=0. We need to show that A(x)A(x)A(x)
has an inverse. To do this, we let B(x)=∑i≥0bixiB(x)=\sum_{i\geq 0}b_i x^iB(x)=∑i≥0​bi​xi and show that
A(x)B(x)=1A(x)B(x)=1A(x)B(x)=1 has a single solution. We can equivalenty solve for:

[xn]A(x)B(x)=∑j=0najbn−j\begin{aligned} [x^n]A(x)B(x) &= \sum_{j=0}^n a_j b_{n-j} \end{aligned}[xn]A(x)B(x)​=j=0∑n​aj​bn−j​​

If n=0n=0n=0, then [x0]A(x)B(x)=a0b0[x^0]A(x)B(x) = a_0b_0[x0]A(x)B(x)=a0​b0​. Comparing this to the [x0][x^0][x0]
coefficient on the Right Hand Side (RHS) of the equation A(x)B(x)=1A(x)B(x)=1A(x)B(x)=1, we get
that a0b0=1a_0b_0 = 1a0​b0​=1, therefore b0=1a0b_0 = \frac{1}{a_0}b0​=a0​1​. This is a valid quotient
since a0a_0a0​ is non-zero by assumption.

If n>0n>0n>0, then [xn]A(x)B(x)=a0bn+∑j=1najbn−j[x^n]A(x)B(x) = a_0b_n + \sum_{j=1}^n a_jb_{n-j}[xn]A(x)B(x)=a0​bn​+∑j=1n​aj​bn−j​. All
coefficents on the RHS of the equation are zero (except the constant term) so
we can solve for bnb_nbn​ from above as
bn=−1a0∑j=1najbn−jb_n = \frac{-1}{a_0}\sum_{j=1}^n a_jb_{n-j}bn​=a0​−1​∑j=1n​aj​bn−j​, which can be solved iteratively
for some desidered value of nnn.
This completes the proof. ■\blacksquare■

The kind of solution obtained for bnb_nbn​ in the above theorem is called a
linear recurrence because bnb_nbn​ is defined as a linear combination of
previous bib_ibi​ terms (for 0≤i<n0\leq i < n0≤i<n). We can use this in solving equations
of formal power series using inverses. This is studied now.

Theorem: Let A(x)A(x)A(x) and C(x)C(x)C(x) be f.p.s. If [x0]A(x)≠0[x^0]A(x)\neq 0[x0]A(x)=0 the there is
a formal power series B(x)B(x)B(x) such that A(x)B(x)=C(x)A(x)B(x) = C(x)A(x)B(x)=C(x).

Proof: This short and simple proof builds off of the conditions for inverses.
Since [x0]A(x)≠0[x^0]A(x) \neq 0[x0]A(x)=0, we know that it has an invserse. Say the inverse of
A(x)A(x)A(x) is B′(x)B'(x)B′(x) i.e. A(x)B′(x)=1A(x)B'(x)=1A(x)B′(x)=1. Now, let B(x)=B′(x)C(x)B(x)=B'(x)C(x)B(x)=B′(x)C(x).
This gives us that A(x)B(x)=(A(x)B′(x))C(x)=C(x)A(x)B(x) = (A(x)B'(x))C(x) = C(x)A(x)B(x)=(A(x)B′(x))C(x)=C(x).
This completes the proof. ■\blacksquare■

Example: Let A(x)=5+x21−xA(x) = \frac{5+x^2}{1-x}A(x)=1−x5+x2​. Compute [xn]A(x)[x^n]A(x)[xn]A(x) for all
n≥0n\geq 0n≥0. Note that in this example, if one considers A(x)A(x)A(x) to be quotient of
polynomials, the one in the denominator has degree lower than the polynomial in
the numerator.

First, start by writing A(x)=(11−x)(5+x2)A(x) = \left(\frac{1}{1-x} \right)\left(5+x^2\right)A(x)=(1−x1​)(5+x2).
Then:

[xn]A(x)=[xn](11−x)(5+x2)=∑k=0n([xk]11−x)([xn−k]5+x2)=∑k=0n[xn−k]5+x2={5  if n∈{0,1}6  if n≥2\begin{aligned} [x^n]A(x) &= [x^n]\left(\frac{1}{1-x} \right)\left(5+x^2\right)\\ &= \sum_{k=0}^n \left( [x^k] \frac{1}{1-x}\right)\left([x^{n-k}]5+x^2\right)\\ &= \sum_{k=0}^n [x^{n-k}]5+x^2\\ &= \begin{cases} 5 &\;\text{if }n\in\{0,1\}\\ 6 &\;\text{if }n\geq 2 \end{cases} \end{aligned}[xn]A(x)​=[xn](1−x1​)(5+x2)=k=0∑n​([xk]1−x1​)([xn−k]5+x2)=k=0∑n​[xn−k]5+x2={56​if n∈{0,1}if n≥2​​

Example: Let A(x)=2+7x−3x21−x2+x3A(x) = \frac{2+7x-3x^2}{1-x^2+x^3}A(x)=1−x2+x32+7x−3x2​. Note that in this
example, if one considers A(x)A(x)A(x) to be a quotient of polynomials the the
polynomial in the denominator has higher degree than the one in the numerator.
In this case, we derive a recurrence relationship which can be used to compute
[xn]A(x)[x^n]A(x)[xn]A(x) for all n≥0n\geq 0n≥0.

Write A(x)=∑k≥0akxkA(x) = \sum_{k\geq 0} a_k x^kA(x)=∑k≥0​ak​xk so that [xn]A(x)=an[x^n]A(x)=a_n[xn]A(x)=an​. Now, rewrite
the original expression for A(x)A(x)A(x) as (1−x2+x3)A(x)=2+7x−3x2(1-x^2+x^3)A(x) = 2+7x-3x^2(1−x2+x3)A(x)=2+7x−3x2.
This process works by essentially comparing coefficients from the Left Hand
Side (LHS) and RHS of the re-arranged expression for A(x)A(x)A(x).

Starting with the constant term. Since the LHS and RHS are equal, we have that
[x0](1−x2+x3)A(x)=[x0]2+7x−3x2[x^0](1-x^2+x^3)A(x) = [x^0]2+7x-3x^2[x0](1−x2+x3)A(x)=[x0]2+7x−3x2. When the expressions for the
coefficients are computed, we get that a0=2a_0 = 2a0​=2.

Next, the linear term: [x1](1−x2+x3)A(x)=[x1]2+7x−3x2[x^1](1-x^2+x^3)A(x) = [x^1]2+7x-3x^2[x1](1−x2+x3)A(x)=[x1]2+7x−3x2. Computing the
expressions on each side of the equation, we get a1(1)−a0(0)=7a_1(1) - a_0(0) = 7a1​(1)−a0​(0)=7.
We get a1=7a_1 = 7a1​=7.

Next, the quadratic term: [x2](1−x2+x3)A(x)=[x2]2+7x−3x2[x^2](1-x^2+x^3)A(x) = [x^2]2+7x-3x^2[x2](1−x2+x3)A(x)=[x2]2+7x−3x2. Computing
the expressions on each side of the equation, we get a2+a1(0)−a0=−3a_2+a_1(0)-a_0 = -3a2​+a1​(0)−a0​=−3.
Evaluating using the previous computations, we get a2=−1a_2 = -1a2​=−1.

Now, we derive a general recurrence using xnx^nxn term, where n≥3n\geq 3n≥3:
[xn](1−x2+x3)A(x)=[xn]2+7x−3x2[x^n](1-x^2+x^3)A(x) = [x^n]2+7x-3x^2[xn](1−x2+x3)A(x)=[xn]2+7x−3x2. Evaluating each side gives
an−an−2+an−3=0a_n - a_{n-2} + a_{n-3} = 0an​−an−2​+an−3​=0. This gives us the expression for the general
ana_nan​ as an=an−2−an−3a_n = a_{n-2} - a_{n-3}an​=an−2​−an−3​ for n≥3n\geq 3n≥3.

The expression ana_nan​ as an=an−2−an−3a_n = a_{n-2} - a_{n-3}an​=an−2​−an−3​ for n≥3n\geq 3n≥3 is called a
recurrence relation. But note that to compute ana_nan​, one needs to know
an−2a_{n-2}an−2​ and an−3a_{n-3}an−3​. Therefore, for the recurrence relation to be of any
use, there must be a set of initial conditions provided. In this case, they
were computed to be a0=2,a1=7a_0 = 2, a_1 = 7a0​=2,a1​=7 and a2=−1a_2 = -1a2​=−1. From this, it is
possible to compute any ana_nan​ iteratively.

Notes: We began to derive a general recurrence relation when we reached the
cubic (or higher) term. This was because the x3x^3x3 term (and all after it)
for the expression on the RHS have zero coefficient.

Also note how the a0a_0a0​ term is non-zero.

Now, more generally, if there are f.p.s. A(x)=∑i≥0aixiA(x)= \sum_{i\geq 0}a_i x^iA(x)=∑i≥0​ai​xi with
a0≠0a_0 \neq 0a0​=0 and C(x)=∑i≥0cixiC(x) = \sum_{i\geq 0}c_i x^iC(x)=∑i≥0​ci​xi. By a theorem, we know that
there exists a B(x)B(x)B(x) such that A(x)B(x)=C(x)A(x)B(x)=C(x)A(x)B(x)=C(x). We know that
B(x)=C(x)A′(x)B(x) = \frac{C(x)}{A'(x)}B(x)=A′(x)C(x)​, where 1A(x)\frac{1}{A(x)}A(x)1​ is the inverse of A(x)A(x)A(x).
We can now derive a general linear recurrence relation defining the
coefficients of B(x)B(x)B(x).

Theorem: Let A(x),C(x)A(x),C(x)A(x),C(x) be formal power series with a0≠0a_0 \neq 0a0​=0. Let
B(x)=C(x)A(x)B(x)=\frac{C(x)}{A(x)}B(x)=A(x)C(x)​. Then, bn=[xn]B(x)b_n = [x^n]B(x)bn​=[xn]B(x) is determined by the linear
recurrence:

bn=1a0(cn−∑j=0n−1an−jbj)b_n = \frac{1}{a_0}\left( c_n - \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} a_{n-j}b_j \right)bn​=a0​1​(cn​−∑j=0n−1​an−j​bj​)

Proof: Again this proof is short and straight-forward: To prove the
recurrence, we start by comparing coefficients of the LHS and RHS i.e.
checking [xn]A(x)B(x)=[xn]C(x)[x^n] A(x)B(x) = [x^n]C(x)[xn]A(x)B(x)=[xn]C(x). We get:

cn=∑j=0najbn−jcn=∑j=0nan−jbjcn=a0bn+∑j=0n−1an−jbj\begin{aligned} c_n &= \sum_{j=0}^n a_j b_{n-j}\\ c_n &= \sum_{j=0}^n a_{n-j} b_{j}\\ c_n &= a_0b_n + \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} a_{n-j} b_{j}\\ \end{aligned}cn​cn​cn​​=j=0∑n​aj​bn−j​=j=0∑n​an−j​bj​=a0​bn​+j=0∑n−1​an−j​bj​​

Rearranging the last equation reveals the desired recurrence:

bn=1a0(cn−∑j=0n−1an−jbj)b_n = \frac{1}{a_0}\left( c_n - \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} a_{n-j}b_j \right)bn​=a0​1​(cn​−∑j=0n−1​an−j​bj​)

COMPOSITION: This is yet another operation defined on formal power series.
Let A(x)=∑j≥0ajxjA(x) = \sum_{j\geq 0}a_j x^jA(x)=∑j≥0​aj​xj and B(x)=∑j≥0bjxjB(x) = \sum_{j\geq 0}b_j x^jB(x)=∑j≥0​bj​xj be formal
power series. If b0=0b_0=0b0​=0 then we define:

A(B(x))=∑j≥0ajB(x)j\begin{aligned} A(B(x)) &= \sum_{j\geq 0} a_j B(x)^j \end{aligned}A(B(x))​=j≥0∑​aj​B(x)j​

In order to verify that composition of formal series is well defined, we check
that the result of composing A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x) as defined above is a formal power
series too.

[xn]A(B(x))=∑j≥0aj[xn]B(x)j\begin{aligned} [x^n]A(B(x)) &= \sum_{j\geq 0} a_j [x^n]B(x)^j \end{aligned}[xn]A(B(x))​=j≥0∑​aj​[xn]B(x)j​

At this stage, note that the logic from multiplicative shift can be applied
here to the term [xn]B(x)j=[xn](b1x+b2x2+… )j[x^n]B(x)^j = [x^n](b_1x+b_2x^2+\dots)^j[xn]B(x)j=[xn](b1​x+b2​x2+…)j. If j>nj>nj>n, then
there are no terms with xnx^nxn left (all terms have exponent xnx^nxn or higher).
Therefore, the sum can be reduced to run from 000 to nnn instead.

[xn]A(B(x))=∑j=0naj[xn]B(x)j<∞\begin{aligned} [x^n]A(B(x)) &= \sum_{j= 0}^n a_j [x^n]B(x)^j\\ &< \infty \end{aligned}[xn]A(B(x))​=j=0∑n​aj​[xn]B(x)j<∞​

The coefficient in finite because aja_jaj​ and [xn]B(x)j[x^n]B(x)^j[xn]B(x)j are all rational and
there is a finite count of summands. Therefore, A(B(x))A(B(x))A(B(x)) is a formal power
series and the operation of composition is well defined.

Note: Here is an example when the condition that b0=0b_0=0b0​=0 is necessary.
Consider the composition of A(x)=∑i≥0xiA(x)=\sum_{i\geq 0}x^iA(x)=∑i≥0​xi and B(x)=1B(x)=1B(x)=1. Then, we get
that A(B(x))=∑j≥01→∞A(B(x))=\sum_{j\geq 0} 1 \rightarrow \inftyA(B(x))=∑j≥0​1→∞. It can cause such problems.

Now, we shall look at using composition of formal power series to compute
inverses.

Theorem: Let A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x) be formal power series such that [x0]A(x)≠0[x^0]A(x)\neq 0[x0]A(x)=0
and [x0]B(x)=0[x^0]B(x)=0[x0]B(x)=0. Then:

[A(B(x))]−1=A−1(B(x))\begin{aligned} [A(B(x))]^{-1} = A^{-1}(B(x)) \end{aligned}[A(B(x))]−1=A−1(B(x))​

Proof: Write A(x)=∑i≥0aixiA(x)=\sum_{i\geq 0}a_i x^iA(x)=∑i≥0​ai​xi. Since a0=0a_0=0a0​=0, we know that A(x)A(x)A(x)
has an inverse. Let A−1(x)=∑i≥0αixiA^{-1}(x)=\sum_{i\geq 0}\alpha_i x^iA−1(x)=∑i≥0​αi​xi. Since [x0]B(x)=0[x^0]B(x)=0[x0]B(x)=0
we know that it can be composed into other formal power series namely A(x)A(x)A(x)
and A−1(x)A^{-1}(x)A−1(x). Let us now consider the product of A(x)A(x)A(x) and A−1(x)A^{-1}(x)A−1(x),
when composed with B(x)B(x)B(x):

A(B(x))A−1(B(x))=(∑j≥0aj[B(x)]j)(∑j≥0αj[B(x)]j)=AA−1(B(x))  by the Multiplicative Rule=1\begin{aligned} A(B(x))A^{-1}(B(x)) &= \left( \sum_{j\geq 0}a_j[B(x)]^j \right) \left( \sum_{j\geq 0}\alpha_j[B(x)]^j \right)\\ &= AA^{-1}(B(x)) \;\text{by the Multiplicative Rule}\\ &= 1 \end{aligned}A(B(x))A−1(B(x))​=(j≥0∑​aj​[B(x)]j)(j≥0∑​αj​[B(x)]j)=AA−1(B(x))by the Multiplicative Rule=1​

This shows us that A(B(x))A(B(x))A(B(x)) is the invserse of A−1(B(x))A^{-1}(B(x))A−1(B(x)) since their
product is 1. Therefore, we get the desired result. ■\blacksquare■

Example: Computing [xn](1+3x)−2(1−x)−1[x^n](1+3x)^{-2}(1-x)^{-1}[xn](1+3x)−2(1−x)−1. The key idea here is to
first express the term (1+3x)−2(1+3x)^{-2}(1+3x)−2 as a composition of formal power series,
then use the theorem above.

Let A(x)=−3xA(x)=-3xA(x)=−3x. So we get that (1+3x)−2=(1−A(x))−2(1+3x)^{-2}=(1-A(x))^{-2}(1+3x)−2=(1−A(x))−2. This is good
because the negative binomial series can be used to obtain a series
representation.

1(1+3x)2=1(1−A(X))2=∑n≥0(n+11)(A(x))n   by the Negative Binomial Series=∑n≥0(n+1)(−3x)n=∑n≥0(−3)n(n+1)xn\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{(1+3x)^{2}} &= \frac{1}{(1-A(X))^{2}}\\ &= \sum_{n\geq 0} \binom{n+1}{1} (A(x))^n \;\text{ by the Negative Binomial Series}\\ &= \sum_{n\geq 0} (n+1)(-3x)^n\\ &= \sum_{n\geq 0} (-3)^n(n+1)x^n \end{aligned}(1+3x)21​​=(1−A(X))21​=n≥0∑​(1n+1​)(A(x))n by the Negative Binomial Series=n≥0∑​(n+1)(−3x)n=n≥0∑​(−3)n(n+1)xn​

This shows us that [xn](1+3x)−2=(−3)n(n+1)[x^n](1+3x)^{-2} = (-3)^n(n+1)[xn](1+3x)−2=(−3)n(n+1).

[xn](1+3x)−2(1−x)−1=∑j=0n[xj](1+3x)−2[xn−j](1−x)−1=∑j=0n[xj](1+3x)−2=∑j=0n(−3)j(j+1)\begin{aligned} [x^n] (1+3x)^{-2} (1-x)^{-1} &= \sum_{j=0}^n [x^j](1+3x)^{-2} [x^{n-j}](1-x)^{-1}\\ &= \sum_{j=0}^n [x^j](1+3x)^{-2}\\ &= \sum_{j=0}^n (-3)^j(j+1) \end{aligned}[xn](1+3x)−2(1−x)−1​=j=0∑n​[xj](1+3x)−2[xn−j](1−x)−1=j=0∑n​[xj](1+3x)−2=j=0∑n​(−3)j(j+1)​

We now have a suite of tools related to formal power series which we shall
employ in our study of generating series- to which we return now...
