Now, we study some additional properties of generating series.

Sum Lemma Let S=A∪BS=A\cup BS=A∪B where A∩B=∅A\cap B = \emptysetA∩B=∅.
Let w:S↦{0,1,… }w:S\mapsto\{0,1,\dots\}w:S↦{0,1,…}. Then

ΦS(x)=ΦA(x)+ΦB(x)\Phi_S(x)=\Phi_A(x)+\Phi_B(x)ΦS​(x)=ΦA​(x)+ΦB​(x)

Proof:

ΦS(x)=∑δ∈Sxw(δ)=∑δ∈Axw(δ)+∑δ∈Bxw(δ)=ΦA(x)+ΦB(x)■\begin{aligned} \Phi_S(x) &= \sum_{\delta\in S} x^{w(\delta)}\\ &= \sum_{\delta\in A}x^{w(\delta)} + \sum_{\delta\in B}x^{w(\delta)}\\ &= \Phi_A(x) + \Phi_B(x)\\ \blacksquare \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)■​=δ∈S∑​xw(δ)=δ∈A∑​xw(δ)+δ∈B∑​xw(δ)=ΦA​(x)+ΦB​(x)​
$

The sum lemma for generating series can be generalised to:

Generalization of Sum Lemma: Let S=A1∪A2∪…AnS=A_1\cup A_2\cup \dots A_nS=A1​∪A2​∪…An​ where
Ai∩Aj=∅A_i\cap A_j = \emptysetAi​∩Aj​=∅ for 1≤i≠j≤n1\leq i\neq j\leq n1≤i=j≤n. Also let
w:S↦{0,1,2,… }w:S\mapsto \{0,1,2,\dots\}w:S↦{0,1,2,…}. Then

ΦS(x)=∑i=0nΦAi(x)\Phi_S(x) = \sum_{i=0}^n \Phi_{A_i}(x)ΦS​(x)=∑i=0n​ΦAi​​(x)

Proof: This is proven by induction on nnn. The base case is trivial.
Assume, inductively that the generalization is true for some nnn. Now we have
to show that it holds for n+1n+1n+1. So we have
S=A1∪A2∪…An∪An+1S=A_1\cup A_2\cup \dots A_n\cup A_{n+1}S=A1​∪A2​∪…An​∪An+1​ and where Ai∩Aj=∅A_i\cap A_j = \emptysetAi​∩Aj​=∅
for all 1≤i≠j≤n+11\leq i\neq j \leq n+11≤i=j≤n+1.

S=A1∪A2∪…An∪An+1=(A1∪A2∪…An)∪An+1\begin{aligned} S &= A_1\cup A_2\cup \dots A_n\cup A_{n+1}\\ &= (A_1\cup A_2\cup \dots A_n)\cup A_{n+1} \end{aligned}S​=A1​∪A2​∪…An​∪An+1​=(A1​∪A2​∪…An​)∪An+1​​

Since SSS is a disjoint union of (A1∪A2∪…An)(A_1\cup A_2\cup \dots A_n)(A1​∪A2​∪…An​) and An+1A_{n+1}An+1​,
we can use the sum lemma:

ΦS(x)=Φ(A1∪A2∪…An)(x)+ΦAn+1(x)=∑i=0nΦAi(x)+ΦAn+1(x)  by Inductive Hypothesis for case n=∑i=0n+1ΦAi(x)■\begin{aligned} \Phi_S(x) &= \Phi_{(A_1\cup A_2\cup \dots A_n)}(x) + \Phi_{A_{n+1}}(x)\\ &= \sum_{i=0}^n \Phi_{A_i}(x) + \Phi_{A_{n+1}}(x) \;\text{by Inductive Hypothesis for case }n\\ &= \sum_{i=0}^{n+1} \Phi_{A_i}(x)\\ \blacksquare \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)■​=Φ(A1​∪A2​∪…An​)​(x)+ΦAn+1​​(x)=i=0∑n​ΦAi​​(x)+ΦAn+1​​(x)by Inductive Hypothesis for case n=i=0∑n+1​ΦAi​​(x)​

Product Lemma: Let A,BA,BA,B be sets with weight functions
α:A↦{0,1,2,… }\alpha:A\mapsto \{0,1,2,\dots\}α:A↦{0,1,2,…} and β:B↦{0,1,2,… }\beta:B\mapsto\{0,1,2,\dots\}β:B↦{0,1,2,…}
respectively. Define a weight function w:A×B↦{0,1,2,… }w:A\times B\mapsto \{0,1,2,\dots\}w:A×B↦{0,1,2,…} by:

w((a,b))=α(a)+β(b)w((a,b))=\alpha(a) + \beta(b)w((a,b))=α(a)+β(b) for all (a,b)∈A×B(a,b)\in A\times B(a,b)∈A×B

Then:

ΦA×B(x)=ΦA(x)ΦB(x)\Phi_{A\times B}(x) = \Phi_{A}(x)\Phi_B(x)ΦA×B​(x)=ΦA​(x)ΦB​(x)

Proof:

ΦA×B=∑δ=(a,b)∈A×Bxw((a,b))=∑δ∈A×Bxα(a)+β(b)=∑a∈A∑b∈Bxα(a)+β(b)=(∑a∈Axα(a))⋅(∑b∈Bxβ(b))=ΦA(x)ΦB(x)■\begin{aligned} \Phi_{A\times B} &= \sum_{\delta=(a,b)\in A\times B} x^{w((a,b))}\\ &= \sum_{\delta\in A\times B} x^{\alpha(a)+\beta(b)}\\ &= \sum_{a\in A}\sum_{b\in B} x^{\alpha(a)+\beta(b)}\\ &= \left( \sum_{a\in A}x^{\alpha(a)} \right)\cdot \left( \sum_{b\in B}x^{\beta(b)} \right)\\ &= \Phi_A(x)\Phi_B(x)\\ \blacksquare \end{aligned}ΦA×B​■​=δ=(a,b)∈A×B∑​xw((a,b))=δ∈A×B∑​xα(a)+β(b)=a∈A∑​b∈B∑​xα(a)+β(b)=(a∈A∑​xα(a))⋅(b∈B∑​xβ(b))=ΦA​(x)ΦB​(x)​

Integer Compositions

Definition: A composition of an integer nnn is a tuple of positive
integers (a1,…,ak)(a_1,\dots, a_k)(a1​,…,ak​) such that ∑i=1kai=n\sum_{i=1}^k a_i = n∑i=1k​ai​=n. We say that this
composition of nnn has kkk parts. Note that a composition is a tuple and
therefore order matters! Furthermore, note that the parts in a integer
composition are strictly positive integers and therefore 0 is not a valid part.

Also, by convention, n=0n=0n=0 has one composition- the empty composition ()()().

The goal is to answer questions of the form: "How many integer compositions of
nnn have some property PPP?" The property PPP could be anything of interest.
Here are some examples:

  • P=P=P= the number of parts is kkk
  • P=P=P= the parts are even
  • P=P=P= the parts are congruent to 1 modulo 3.

The general strategy to solve such problems is as follows:

  1. Define a set, say SSS, which contains all of the intger compositions with the
    property PPP.
  2. Define an appropriate weight function www, such that the solution to the
    question of interest is given by [xn]ΦS(x)[x^n]\Phi_S(x)[xn]ΦS​(x).
  3. Compute the generating series of SSS, with respect to the weight function
    www, ΦS(x)\Phi_S(x)ΦS​(x).
  4. Finally, compute [xn]ΦS(x)[x^n]\Phi_S(x)[xn]ΦS​(x).

The toolbox that will allow us to perform these steps includes the following:

  • Sum lemma: if A∩B=∅A\cap B = \emptysetA∩B=∅, then ΦA∪B(x)=ΦA(x)+ΦB(x)\Phi_{A\cup B}(x)=\Phi_A(x) + \Phi_B(x)ΦA∪B​(x)=ΦA​(x)+ΦB​(x)
  • Product lemma: with the condition of the weight functions satisfied, one has
    ΦA×B(x)=ΦA(x)ΦB(x)\Phi_{A\times B}(x) = \Phi_A(x)\Phi_B(x)ΦA×B​(x)=ΦA​(x)ΦB​(x)
  • Power shifts: [xn]xkA(x)={[xn−k]A(x) if n≥k0 if n<k[x^n]x^kA(x) = \begin{cases} [x^{n-k}]A(x) &\text{ if }n\geq k\\ 0 &\text{ if }n<k \end{cases}[xn]xkA(x)={[xn−k]A(x)0​ if n≥k if n<k​
  • Geometric series: ∑i=0∞xi=11−x\sum_{i=0}^\infty x^i = \frac{1}{1-x}∑i=0∞​xi=1−x1​
  • Composition of geometric series: If [x0]A(x)=0[x^0]A(x) = 0[x0]A(x)=0, then ∑i=0∞(A(x))i=11−A(x)\sum_{i=0}^\infty (A(x))^i = \frac{1}{1-A(x)}∑i=0∞​(A(x))i=1−A(x)1​
  • Negative binomal series: 1(1−x)k=∑n=0∞(n+k−1k−1)xn\frac{1}{(1-x)^k}=\sum_{n=0}^\infty \binom{n+k-1}{k-1} x^n(1−x)k1​=∑n=0∞​(k−1n+k−1​)xn

Example: Compute the number of compositions of nnn with kkk parts.

First, we need a set which contains all the integer compositions with kkk parts.
Let S=NkS=N^kS=Nk, where N={1,2,3,… }N=\{1,2,3,\dots\}N={1,2,3,…}.

Then, define an appropriate weight function. Let w:S↦{0,1,2,… }w:S\mapsto \{0,1,2,\dots\}w:S↦{0,1,2,…} be
defined as follows: for all X=(x1,…,xk)∈SX=(x_1,\dots,x_k)\in SX=(x1​,…,xk​)∈S, w(X)=∑i=0kxiw(X)=\sum_{i=0}^k x_iw(X)=∑i=0k​xi​.

With these definitions in place, the answer to the "number of compositions of
nnn which have kkk parts" is just [xn]ΦS(x)[x^n]\Phi_S(x)[xn]ΦS​(x). We now compute it.

ΦS(x)=ΦNk(x)=(ΦN(x))kProduct Lemma=(∑j≥1xj)j=xk(1−x)k\begin{aligned} \Phi_S(x) &= \Phi_{N^k}(x)\\ &= \left( \Phi_N(x) \right)^k &\text{Product Lemma}\\ &= \left( \sum_{j\geq 1} x^j \right)^j\\ &= \frac{x^k}{(1-x)^k} \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)​=ΦNk​(x)=(ΦN​(x))k=(j≥1∑​xj)j=(1−x)kxk​​Product Lemma

Now, using the multiplicative shift rule, one sees that:

[xn]ΦS(x)={0 if n<k(n−1k−1) if n≥k\begin{aligned} [x^n]\Phi_S(x) &= \begin{cases} 0 &\text{ if } n< k\\ \binom{n-1}{k-1} &\text{ if } n\geq k \end{cases} \end{aligned}[xn]ΦS​(x)​={0(k−1n−1​)​ if n<k if n≥k​​

The last case evaluates to the binomial coefficient given because of the
negative binomial theorem.

Binary Strings

This is another object which can be studied very interestingly with the concepts of generating series. First, some definitions regarding binary strings:

Definition: A binary string (a.k.a. {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1}-string) is a strings consisting of only ones and zeroes. The length of a binary string is defined to be the total number of ones and zeroes in the string.

Definition: bbb is a substring of sss if s=abcs=abcs=abc for some binary strings a,ca,ca,c (which could possibly be empty strings). The expression abcabcabc will become clear when concatenation is defined soon.

Definition: A block in a binary string is a maximal, non-empty substring which consists of only ones or only zeroes.

Definition: Concatenation of two binary strings a,ba,ba,b is the string ababab.

Definition: If AAA and BBB are sets of binary strings, we define
AB={ab∣a∈A and b∈B}AB=\{ab|a\in A \text{ and }b\in B\}AB={ab∣a∈A and b∈B}. So ABABAB is the set consisting of all the concatenations of a string in AAA with a string in BBB.

Also, AkA^kAk is defined to be A⋅A⋅⋯⋅AA\cdot A\cdot \dots \cdot AA⋅A⋅⋯⋅A, kkk times. Note that this notation is overloaded with the Cartesian product for regular sets.

Definition: For any set AAA of binary strings, define the star operation as follows:

A∗={ϵ}∪A∪A2∪…=∪k=0∞Ak\begin{aligned} A^* &= \{\epsilon\}\cup A \cup A^2 \cup \dots \\ &= \cup_{k=0}^\infty A^k \end{aligned}A∗​={ϵ}∪A∪A2∪…=∪k=0∞​Ak​

where ϵ\epsilonϵ is defined to be the empty string (which has length 0).

With this star operation, it is possible to define the set of all binary strings as {0,1}∗\{0,1\}^*{0,1}∗. It also allows us to create more specific sets of strings (which, as in the case of integer compositions is the first step in solving a combinatorial problem involving binary strings). For example, the set {0}{00}∗\{0\}\{00\}^*{0}{00}∗ contains all of the strings of odd length containing only
zeroes.

The goal is to be able to answer questions of the form "How many binary strings of length nnn have property PPP?". Again, property PPP could be anything of interest in the context of binary strings:

  • P=P=P= no adjacent ones
  • P=P=P= exactly kkk occurrences of the substring 110110110
  • P=P=P= no occurrences of the substring 111111111.

The strategy is very similar to the one used for integer compositions:

  1. Devise a set SSS of all binary strings which have the desired property PPP
  2. Let w:S↦{0,1,2,… }w:S\mapsto \{0,1,2,\dots\}w:S↦{0,1,2,…} be a weight function which, for all σ∈S\sigma \in Sσ∈S, w(σ)=w(\sigma)=w(σ)= length of σ\sigmaσ.
  3. The desired answer will then be [xn]ΦS(x)[x^n]\Phi_S(x)[xn]ΦS​(x)

While the strategy may be the same as the one for integer compositions, binary strings have some nuances which require that the set of tools (specifically the product and sum lemmas) to be readjustment to handle the nuances. In particular, one may not immediately see how the product lemma may be used for binary strings as there is no operation of Cartesian products, just concatenation and these two are not the same.

Consider the two sets of binary strings A={010,01}A = \{ 010, 01 \}A={010,01} and B={0,00}B = \{ 0, 00 \}B={0,00}. The Cartesian product A×BA\times BA×B has 4 elements. But observe the set of strings in the set AB={0100,10100,101}AB = \{ 0100, 10100, 101 \}AB={0100,10100,101}. Note that the product lemma does not hold in this case: ΦAB(x)=x3+x4+x5\Phi_{AB}(x) = x^3 + x^4 + x^5ΦAB​(x)=x3+x4+x5 and this is not the product of ΦA(x)=x2+x3\Phi_A(x) = x^2 + x^3ΦA​(x)=x2+x3 and ΦB(x)=x+x2\Phi_B(x) = x + x^2ΦB​(x)=x+x2. In particular, one cannot draw a bijection between ABABAB and A×BA\times BA×B- there are two elements in A×BA\times BA×B, namely (010,0)(010, 0)(010,0) and (01,00)(01, 00)(01,00) which map to the same string "0100" in ABABAB. To deal with this, we introduce the concept of ambiguity:

Definition: Let AAA and BBB be sets of binary strings. The expression ABABAB is ambiguous if there exist a1,a2∈Aa_1,a_2 \in Aa1​,a2​∈A and b1,b2∈Bb_1, b_2 \in Bb1​,b2​∈B such that a1b1=a2b2a_1b_1 = a_2b_2a1​b1​=a2​b2​.

The expression A∪BA\cup BA∪B is ambiguous if A∩B≠∅A\cap B \neq \emptysetA∩B=∅.

An expression involving concatenations and unions of sets of binary strings is ambiguous if any of the constituent concatenations or unions of sets is ambiguous.

An expression is said to be unambiguous iff it is not ambiguous.

Using this definition, for example, the set AkA^kAk is ambiguous if there exist a1,…,ak,a1′,…ak′∈Aa_1, \dots, a_k, a_1', \dots a_k' \in Aa1​,…,ak​,a1′​,…ak′​∈A such that (a1,…,ak)≠(a1′,…,ak′)(a_1,\dots, a_k)\neq (a_1', \dots, a_k')(a1​,…,ak​)=(a1′​,…,ak′​) and a1…ak=a1′…ak′a_1\dots a_k = a_1'\dots a_k'a1​…ak​=a1′​…ak′​.

Example: Show that the expression {0}{00}∗\{ 0 \} \{ 00 \}^*{0}{00}∗ is unambiguous.

First, we show that the star operation is unambiguous. The set {00}={ϵ}∪{00}∪{00}2∪…\{ 00 \} = \{ \epsilon \} \cup \{ 00 \} \cup \{ 00 \}^2 \cup \dots{00}={ϵ}∪{00}∪{00}2∪…. Firstly, these are clearly disjoint unions. Next, note that the set {00}k\{ 00 \}^k{00}k is unambiguous for all k≥0k\geq 0k≥0; we have that {00}k={00…00⏟2k zeros}\{ 00 \}^k = \{ \underbrace{00\dots 00}_\text{2k zeros} \}{00}k={2k zeros00…00​​}.

Next, the concatenation with {0}\{ 0 \}{0} is unambiguous. If we have two strings 0b=0b′0b = 0b'0b=0b′, then clearly b=b′b = b'b=b′. So the expression {0}{00}∗\{ 0 \} \{ 00 \}^*{0}{00}∗ is unambiguous.

Now, here are some very useful unambiguous expressions for the set of all binary strings. They are important because they can be "refined" to smaller unambiguous sets.

  • {0,1}\{ 0, 1 \}{0,1}. This one is trivial.
  • {0}∗({1}{0}∗)∗\{ 0 \}^* \left( \{ 1 \} \{ 0 \}^* \right)^*{0}∗({1}{0}∗)∗. In this expression, a binary
    string is split by the ones in the string.
  • {0}∗({1}{1}∗{0}{0}∗)∗{1}∗\{ 0 \}^* \left( \{ 1 \} \{ 1 \}^* \{ 0 \} \{ 0 \}^* \right)^* \{ 1 \}^*{0}∗({1}{1}∗{0}{0}∗)∗{1}∗. This expression is called the block decomposition of the set of binary strings. A binary string here is viewed as a block of ones followed by a block of zeros, with a possible starting block of zeros and a possible ending block of ones.

Note: One may find it important to know that by the laws of symmetry, it is perfectly acceptable and valid to switch the ones and zeros in the above ambiguous expressions and end up with a valid unambiguous expression.

Depending on the situation, one of these expressions will be easier to manipulate to reduce it into a set of binary strings with desired properties. For example, in a question specifying conditions on the blocks of ones and the blocks of zeros, the block decomposition may be a good place to start.

Example: Derive an expression for the set of all binary strings with no 3 consecutive zeros.

Since this question only deals with the blocks of zeros, we can use the second one of the unambiguous decompositions and refine it down to an expression for the set of all binary strings with no 3 consecutive zeros.

In the expression {0}∗({1}{0}∗)∗\{ 0 \}^* \left( \{ 1 \} \{ 0 \}^* \right)^*{0}∗({1}{0}∗)∗, the parts of concern are the ones with zeros. The set {0}∗={ϵ,0,00,… }\{ 0 \}^* = \{ \epsilon, 0, 00, \dots \}{0}∗={ϵ,0,00,…} needs to be reduced down to the set {ϵ,0,00}\{ \epsilon, 0, 00 \}{ϵ,0,00}.

Replacing {0}∗\{ 0 \}^*{0}∗ with this reduced set in the unambiguous expression above results in the following set {ϵ,0,00}∗({1}{ϵ,0,00})∗\{ \epsilon, 0, 00 \}^* \left( \{ 1 \} \{ \epsilon, 0, 00 \} \right)^*{ϵ,0,00}∗({1}{ϵ,0,00})∗ which is an unambiguous expression for the set of all binary strings which have no 3 consecutive zeros.

Equipped with this concept of unambiguity, one modification needs to be made before computing generating series for sets of binary strings. This is that the expression for the set SSS needs to be unambiguous in order to sanely compute its generating series. Here are some theorems to aid with this goal:

Theorem: Let AAA and BBB be sets of binary strings.

  1. If ABABAB is unambiguous, then ΦAB(x)=ΦA(x)ΦB(x)\Phi_{AB}(x) = \Phi_A(x) \Phi_B(x)ΦAB​(x)=ΦA​(x)ΦB​(x). This is
    called the product lemma for binary strings
  2. If A∪BA\cup BA∪B is unabiguous, then ΦA∪B(x)=ΦA(x)+ΦB(x)\Phi_{A\cup B}(x) = \Phi_A(x) + \Phi_B(x)ΦA∪B​(x)=ΦA​(x)+ΦB​(x).
    This is called the sum lemma for binary strings.
  3. If A∗A^*A∗ is unambiguous, then ΦA∗(x)=11−ΦA(x)\Phi_{A^*}(x) = \frac{1}{1 - \Phi_A(x)}ΦA∗​(x)=1−ΦA​(x)1​. This
    is called the star rule.

Proof:

Let l(x)l(x)l(x) be the function which returns the length of the binary string xxx. This is the default weight function for binary strings, unless otherwise specified.

  1. In this case, note that an element σ∈AB\sigma \in ABσ∈AB is unambiguously a concatenation of some element a∈Aa\in Aa∈A with a b∈Bb\in Bb∈B.
    ΦAB(x)=∑σ∈ABxl(σ)=∑a∈A and b∈Bxl(ab)=∑a∈A and b∈Bxl(a)+l(b)=(∑a∈Axl(a))(∑b∈Bxl(b))=ΦA(x)ΦB(x)\begin{aligned} \Phi_{AB}(x) &= \sum_{\sigma \in AB} x^{l(\sigma)}\\ &= \sum_{a\in A \text{ and } b\in B} x^{l(ab)}\\ &= \sum_{a\in A \text{ and } b\in B} x^{l(a) + l(b)}\\ &= \left( \sum_{a\in A} x^{l(a)} \right) \left( \sum_{b\in B} x^{l(b)} \right)\\ &= \Phi_A(x) \Phi_B(x) \end{aligned}ΦAB​(x)​=σ∈AB∑​xl(σ)=a∈A and b∈B∑​xl(ab)=a∈A and b∈B∑​xl(a)+l(b)=(a∈A∑​xl(a))(b∈B∑​xl(b))=ΦA​(x)ΦB​(x)​

  2. This case is pretty simple as A∪BA\cup BA∪B is unambiguous iff it is a disjoint union. Therefore the sum lemma can be used.

    ΦA∪B(x)=ΦA(x)+ΦB(x)\Phi_{A\cup B}(x) = \Phi_A(x) + \Phi_B(x)ΦA∪B​(x)=ΦA​(x)+ΦB​(x)

  3. We rewrite A∗=∪k=0∞AkA^* = \cup_{k=0}^\infty A^kA∗=∪k=0∞​Ak. Since Ai∩Aj=∅A^i \cap A^j = \emptysetAi∩Aj=∅ for all 0≤i≠j0 \leq i \neq j0≤i=j, the sum lemma can be applied. Also, since each AkA^kAk is unambiguous for all k≥0k\geq 0k≥0, the product lemma may be applied.

    ΦA∗(x)=∑k=0∞ΦAk(x)Sum lemma=∑k=0∞[ΦA(x)]kProduct lemma\begin{aligned} \Phi_{A^*}(x) &= \sum_{k=0}^\infty \Phi_{A^k}(x) &\text{Sum lemma}\\ &= \sum_{k=0}^\infty \left[ \Phi_A(x) \right]^k &\text{Product lemma} \end{aligned}ΦA∗​(x)​=k=0∑∞​ΦAk​(x)=k=0∑∞​[ΦA​(x)]k​Sum lemmaProduct lemma​

    Now, this last term looks like a composition with the geometric series, but to be sure, we have to verify that [x0]ΦA(x)=0[x^0] \Phi_A(x) = 0[x0]ΦA​(x)=0. Note that A0={ϵ}A^0 = \{ \epsilon \}A0={ϵ} and that Aj∩Ai=∅A^j \cap A^i = \emptysetAj∩Ai=∅ for all 0≤i≠j0\leq i\neq j0≤i=j by the unambiguity of A∗A^*A∗. This means that ϵ∉A\epsilon \notin Aϵ∈/A and so there is no string in AAA with length 0, so the constant term of ΦA(x)\Phi_A(x)ΦA​(x) must be 0- so this is indeed a valid composition. Finally, we get:

    ΦA∗(x)=∑k=0∞[ΦA(x)]k=11−ΦA(x)\begin{aligned} \Phi_{A^*}(x) &= \sum_{k=0}^\infty \left[ \Phi_A(x) \right]^k \\ &= \frac{1}{1-\Phi_A(x)} \end{aligned}ΦA∗​(x)​=k=0∑∞​[ΦA​(x)]k=1−ΦA​(x)1​​

Example: Compute the number of binary strings of length nnn with no substring 111111.

First, we need an unambiguous expression for the set of all binary strings with no substring 111111. We can use symmetry and reverse one of the unambiguous expressions for the set of all binary strings to get a good starting point. We reverse the ones and zeros in the unambiguous expression {0}∗({1}{0}∗)∗\{ 0 \}^* \left( \{ 1 \} \{ 0 \}^* \right)^*{0}∗({1}{0}∗)∗ to get {1}∗({0}{1}∗)∗\{ 1 \}^* \left( \{ 0 \} \{ 1 \}^* \right)^*{1}∗({0}{1}∗)∗. Now, we refine this expression down so that every block of ones does not contain the substring 11. This gives the expression S={ϵ,1}({0}{ϵ,1})∗S = \{ \epsilon, 1 \} \left( \{ 0 \} \{ \epsilon, 1 \} \right)^*S={ϵ,1}({0}{ϵ,1})∗.

Now, proceeding to compute the generating series of the set SSS with respect to string length as the weight function. Note that the product and star rules may be applied because the expression for SSS above is unambiguous.

ΦS(x)=Φ{ϵ,1}(x)Φ({0}{ϵ,1})∗(x)Product lemma=Φ{ϵ,1}(x)1−Φ{0}{ϵ,1}(x)Star rule=Φ{ϵ,1}(x)1−Φ{0}(x)Φ{ϵ,1}(x)Product rule=1+x1−x(1+x)=1+x1−x−x2\begin{aligned} \Phi_{S}(x) &= \Phi_{\{ \epsilon, 1 \}}(x) \Phi_{\left( \{ 0 \} \{ \epsilon, 1 \} \right)^*}(x) &\text{Product lemma}\\ &= \frac{ \Phi_{\{ \epsilon, 1 \}}(x) }{ 1 - \Phi_{\{ 0 \} \{ \epsilon, 1 \}}(x)} &\text{Star rule}\\ &= \frac{ \Phi_{\{ \epsilon, 1 \}}(x) }{ 1 - \Phi_{\{ 0 \}}(x) \Phi_{\{ \epsilon, 1 \}}(x)} &\text{Product rule}\\ &= \frac{ 1 + x }{ 1 - x(1 + x) } \\ &= \frac{ 1 + x }{ 1 - x - x^2 } \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)​=Φ{ϵ,1}​(x)Φ({0}{ϵ,1})∗​(x)=1−Φ{0}{ϵ,1}​(x)Φ{ϵ,1}​(x)​=1−Φ{0}​(x)Φ{ϵ,1}​(x)Φ{ϵ,1}​(x)​=1−x(1+x)1+x​=1−x−x21+x​​Product lemmaStar ruleProduct rule​

With this expression, note that we can do the following simplification:

[xn]ΦA(x)=[xn]11−x−x2+[xn]x1−x−x2=[xn]11−x−x2+[xn−1]11−x−x2=fn+fn−1\begin{aligned} [x^n] \Phi_A(x) &= [x^n] \frac{1}{ 1 - x - x^2 } + [x^n] \frac{x}{ 1 - x - x^2}\\ &= [x^n]\frac{1}{ 1 - x - x^2 } + [x^{n-1}]\frac{1}{ 1 - x - x^2 }\\ &= f_n + f_{n-1} \end{aligned}[xn]ΦA​(x)​=[xn]1−x−x21​+[xn]1−x−x2x​=[xn]1−x−x21​+[xn−1]1−x−x21​=fn​+fn−1​​

where fn=[xn]11−x−x2f_n = [x^n]\frac{1}{ 1 - x - x^2 }fn​=[xn]1−x−x21​. This is actually part of the Fibonacci sequence. Computing the starting terms of fnf_nfn​ is easy by comparing coefficients. We get f0=f1=1f_0 = f_1 = 1f0​=f1​=1. Putting all of this together, we finally get that:

[xn]ΦS(x)={1 if n=0fn+fn−1 if n≥1\begin{aligned} [x^n]\Phi_S(x) &= \begin{cases} 1 &\text{ if } n = 0\\ f_{n} + f_{n - 1} &\text{ if } n\geq 1 \end{cases} \end{aligned}[xn]ΦS​(x)​={1fn​+fn−1​​ if n=0 if n≥1​​

This makes intutive sense. When n=0n=0n=0, there is clearly only one string with length 0, which does not contain the substring 111111, namely the empty string. Then, there are two strings of length 1 which do not contain the string 111111 and so on.

Recursive Decompositions

Sometimes, recursive definitions can help to make computation of generating series easier. Note that recursive decompositions are just expressions and the rules that have so far been used to compute generating series will still be used with them, just with collection of like terms to get the final series.

Here is an example. Let us derive a recursive decomposition for the set of all binary strings, say SSS. One way to approach this is by selecting an arbitrary string in SSS and analysing it to see what could come next. In this case, any binary string could start with either a 111 or a 000 and it could be followed by a sequence of ones or zeros i.e. another binary string. Or, the binary string could simply be the empty string. This gives us the simple recursive definition for the set of all binary strings as S={ϵ}∪{0,1}SS = \{ \epsilon \} \cup \{ 0, 1 \}SS={ϵ}∪{0,1}S.

Now, let us try to compute the generating series of this set SSS with this representation. Note that we can still use the product lemma here as the concatenation is clearly unambiguous and the sum lemma because the union is disjoint.

ΦS(x)=Φ{ϵ}(x)+Φ{0,1}S(x)Sum lemma=1+Φ{0,1}(x)ΦS(x)Product lemma=1+2xΦS(x)\begin{aligned} \Phi_S(x) &= \Phi_{ \{ \epsilon \} }(x) + \Phi_{ \{ 0, 1 \} S }(x) &\text{Sum lemma}\\ &= 1 + \Phi_{ \{ 0, 1 \} }(x) \Phi_S(x) &\text{Product lemma}\\ &= 1 + 2x \Phi_S(x) \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)​=Φ{ϵ}​(x)+Φ{0,1}S​(x)=1+Φ{0,1}​(x)ΦS​(x)=1+2xΦS​(x)​Sum lemmaProduct lemma​

By collecting like terms, one ends up with the generating series: ΦS(x)=11−2x\Phi_S(x) = \frac{1}{1-2x}ΦS​(x)=1−2x1​.

Example: Another example is an expression for the set of all binary strings
with no substring 111111. Let the set of all such strings be SSS.

Firstly, a string in SSS is either the empty string, starts with a one or starts with a zero. Let A0A_0A0​ be the set of all binary strings which start with a zero. And let A1A_1A1​ be the set of all binary strings which start with a one. So S={ϵ}∪A0∪A1S = \{ \epsilon \} \cup A_0 \cup A_1S={ϵ}∪A0​∪A1​. Note that this is a disjoint union of sets and so the sun lemma is applicable.

Here are some observations that will make life easier. Firstly, an element in A0A_0A0​ is such that it begins with a 000 and then a sequence of ones and zeros follow i.e. another binary string. Therefore, we get the expression A0={0}SA_0 = \{ 0 \} SA0​={0}S. Similarly, an element in A1A_1A1​ is either the string 111 or the string 111 concatenated to the beginning of every string in A0A_0A0​. More precisely, A1={1}∪{1}A0A_1 = \{ 1 \} \cup \{ 1 \} A_0A1​={1}∪{1}A0​. Now, we can use these expressions in order to compute the generating series of the set SSS.

ΦS(x)=Φ{ϵ}(x)+Φ{0}S(x)+Φ{1}(x)+Φ{1}{0}S(x)Sum lemma=Φ{ϵ}(x)+Φ{0}(x)ΦS(x)+Φ{1}(x)+Φ{1}(x)Φ{0}(x)ΦS(x)Product lemma=1+xΦS(x)+x+x2ΦS(x)\begin{aligned} \Phi_S(x) &= \Phi_{ \{ \epsilon \} }(x) + \Phi_{ \{ 0 \} S }(x) + \Phi_{ \{ 1 \} }(x) + \Phi_{ \{ 1 \} \{ 0 \} S }(x) &\text{Sum lemma}\\ &= \Phi_{ \{ \epsilon \} }(x) + \Phi_{ \{ 0 \} }(x) \Phi_S(x) + \Phi_{ \{ 1 \} }(x) + \Phi_{ \{ 1 \} }(x) \Phi_{ \{ 0 \} }(x) \Phi_{ S }(x) &\text{Product lemma}\\ &= 1 + x\Phi_S(x) + x + x^2\Phi_S(x) \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)​=Φ{ϵ}​(x)+Φ{0}S​(x)+Φ{1}​(x)+Φ{1}{0}S​(x)=Φ{ϵ}​(x)+Φ{0}​(x)ΦS​(x)+Φ{1}​(x)+Φ{1}​(x)Φ{0}​(x)ΦS​(x)=1+xΦS​(x)+x+x2ΦS​(x)​Sum lemmaProduct lemma​

By collecting like terms and solving for ΦS(x)\Phi_S(x)ΦS​(x) yields

ΦS(x)=1+x1−x−x2\begin{aligned} \Phi_S(x) &= \frac{ 1 + x }{ 1 - x - x^2 } \end{aligned}ΦS​(x)​=1−x−x21+x​​

This is the same answer as the one obtained when using unambiguous expressions.

Coefficients of Rational Functions

This is a new tool that can be used when solving combinatorial problems such as the ones being dealt above. Specifically, these are tools for computing [xn]f(x)g(x)[x^n] \frac{ f(x) }{ g(x) }[xn]g(x)f(x)​ where f,gf,gf,g are polynomials.

A starting point will be the method of partial fractions. In specific cases, it can be used to split a rational polynomial to a form where its coefficients are easy to compute using composition with geometric series or the negative binomial series.

The method of partial fractions will be generalized to rational fractions of the form f(x)g(x)\frac{ f(x) }{ g(x) }g(x)f(x)​ where f,gf,gf,g are polynomials and deg⁡(f)<deg⁡(g)\deg( f ) < \deg( g )deg(f)<deg(g) and [x0]g(x)=0[x^0] g(x) = 0[x0]g(x)=0.

Notes: Here are some points before proceeding:

  • Without loss of generality (WLOG), we can assume that [xn]g(x)=1[x^n] g(x) = 1[xn]g(x)=1 since it is non-zero- this is fine because it can be scaled to 1 anyway by multiplying the numerator and denominator by a constant.

  • By the fundamental theorem of algebra, ggg can be factorized over the complex numbers as g(x)=(α1−x)e1…(αk−x)ekg(x) = (\alpha_1 - x)^{e_1} \dots (\alpha_k - x)^{e_k}g(x)=(α1​−x)e1​…(αk​−x)ek​. Note that the multiplicities e1,…,ek≥1e_1, \dots, e_k \geq 1e1​,…,ek​≥1 and ∑i=0kei=deg⁡(g)\sum_{i=0}^k e_i = \deg( g )∑i=0k​ei​=deg(g). Also, the values α1,…,αk∈C∖{0}\alpha_1, \dots, \alpha_k \in \mathbf{C}\setminus \{ 0 \}α1​,…,αk​∈C∖{0}- they must be non-zero complex numbers since the constant term of ggg is non-zero.

    Furthermore, if we let ri=αi−1r_i = \alpha_i^{-1}ri​=αi−1​ for 1≤i≤k1\leq i \leq k1≤i≤k, Since the constant term of ggg is effectively 111, we can re-write it as:
    g(x)=(1−r1x)e1…(1−rkx)ekg(x) = ( 1 - r_1 x )^{e_1} \dots ( 1 - r_k x )^{e_k}g(x)=(1−r1​x)e1​…(1−rk​x)ek​

Now, we generalize the theorem of partial fractions. This will be just the statement and not the proof (I may include the proof at a later time).

Theorem [ Partial Fractions ]: Suppose f,gf,gf,g are polynomials with deg⁡(f)<deg⁡(g)\deg(f) < \deg( g )deg(f)<deg(g) and g(x)=(1−r1x)e1…(1−rkx)ekg(x) = ( 1 - r_1 x )^{e_1} \dots ( 1 - r_k x )^{e_k}g(x)=(1−r1​x)e1​…(1−rk​x)ek​ with r1,…,rkr_1, \dots, r_kr1​,…,rk​ distinct complex numbers and e1,…,eke_1, \dots, e_ke1​,…,ek​ are integers greater that one which add up to the degree of ggg. Then:

f(x)g(x)=C1,1(1−r1x)+C1,2(1−r1x)2+⋯+C1,e1(1−r1x)e1+C2,1(1−r2x)+C2,2(1−r2x)2+⋯+C1,e2(1−r2x)e2⋮+Ck,1(1−rkx)+Ck,2(1−rkx)2+⋯+Ck,ek(1−rkx)ek\begin{aligned} \frac{ f(x) }{ g(x) } &= \frac{C_{1,1}}{(1-r_1x)} + \frac{C_{1,2}}{(1-r_1x)^2} + \dots + \frac{C_{1,e_1}}{(1-r_1x)^{e_1}} \\ &+ \frac{C_{2,1}}{(1-r_2x)} + \frac{C_{2,2}}{(1-r_2x)^2} + \dots + \frac{C_{1,e_2}}{(1-r_2x)^{e_2}} \\ &\vdots \\ &+ \frac{C_{k,1}}{(1-r_kx)} + \frac{C_{k,2}}{(1-r_kx)^2} + \dots + \frac{C_{k,e_k}}{(1-r_kx)^{e_k}} \end{aligned}g(x)f(x)​​=(1−r1​x)C1,1​​+(1−r1​x)2C1,2​​+⋯+(1−r1​x)e1​C1,e1​​​+(1−r2​x)C2,1​​+(1−r2​x)2C2,2​​+⋯+(1−r2​x)e2​C1,e2​​​⋮+(1−rk​x)Ck,1​​+(1−rk​x)2Ck,2​​+⋯+(1−rk​x)ek​Ck,ek​​​​

for complex coefficients {C1,1,…,Ck,ek}\{ C_{1,1}, \dots, C_{k, e_k} \}{C1,1​,…,Ck,ek​​}.

This is useful because it allows one to reduce a quotient of polynomial to a state where it can be dealt with using the negative binomial theorem. For example, the quotient A(x)=2+2x2(1−2x)(1−7x)A(x) = \frac{ 2 + 2x^2 }{ (1-2x)(1-7x) }A(x)=(1−2x)(1−7x)2+2x2​ can be reduced to a much more friendly form:

A(x)=−11−2x−1(1−2x)2+41−7x\begin{aligned} A(x) &= \frac{-1}{ 1 - 2x } - \frac{1}{ ( 1 - 2x )^2 } + \frac{4}{ 1 - 7x } \end{aligned}A(x)​=1−2x−1​−(1−2x)21​+1−7x4​​

In this form, one can easily compute the coefficient of the xnx^nxn using the negative binomial series for each individual term. This results in the following answer: [xn]A(x)=2n(−n−2)+4⋅7n[x^n] A(x) = 2^n ( -n -2 ) + 4\cdot 7^n[xn]A(x)=2n(−n−2)+4⋅7n.

Theorem: Suppose that f,gf,gf,g are polynomials with deg⁡(f)<deg⁡(g)\deg(f) < \deg(g)deg(f)<deg(g) and ggg is of the form g(x)=(1−r1x)e1…(1−rkx)ekg(x) = (1-r_1x)^{e_1} \dots (1-r_kx)^{e_k}g(x)=(1−r1​x)e1​…(1−rk​x)ek​. Then, there exist polynomials p1.…,pkp_1. \dots, p_kp1​.…,pk​ such that deg⁡(pi)≤ei\deg( p_i ) \leq e_ideg(pi​)≤ei​ for 1≤i≤k1\leq i \leq k1≤i≤k and [xn]f(x)g(x)=p1(x)r1n+⋯+pk(x)rkn[x^n] \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = p_1(x)r_1^n + \dots + p_k(x)r_k^n[xn]g(x)f(x)​=p1​(x)r1n​+⋯+pk​(x)rkn​.

Proof: This comes pretty simply using the following claim, applied to the generalised partial fractions theorem.

Claim: Let c,r∈Cc,r \in \mathbf{C}c,r∈C and j≥1j\geq 1j≥1. Then there is a degree j−1j-1j−1 polynomial qqq such that [xn]c(1−rx)j=q(n)rn[x^n] \frac{ c }{ (1-rx)^j } = q(n)r^n[xn](1−rx)jc​=q(n)rn.

Proof of claim: We can use the negative binomial series here to expand the formal power series into a summation and then extract its coefficient as follows:

[xn]c(1−rx)j=[xn]c∑k≥0(k+j−1j−1)(rx)j=c(n+j−1j−1)rn=crn(n+j−1)(n+j−2)…(n+1)(j−1)!\begin{aligned} [x^n] \frac{c}{(1-rx)^j} &= [x^n] c \sum_{k\geq 0} \binom{k + j - 1}{j - 1} (rx)^j\\ &= c \binom{n+j-1}{j-1} r^n\\ &= cr^n \frac{(n+j-1)(n+j-2)\dots (n+1)}{(j-1)!} \end{aligned}[xn](1−rx)jc​​=[xn]ck≥0∑​(j−1k+j−1​)(rx)j=c(j−1n+j−1​)rn=crn(j−1)!(n+j−1)(n+j−2)…(n+1)​​

Note that the numerator has the form of a polynomial in xxx evaluated at a value nnn and the denominator is not at all dependent on nnn. This motivates us to define q(x)=c(j−1)!(x+j−1)(x+j−2)…(x+1)q(x) = \frac{c}{(j-1)!}(x+j-1)(x+j-2)\dots (x+1)q(x)=(j−1)!c​(x+j−1)(x+j−2)…(x+1), which is indeed a degree j−1j-1j−1 polynomial. This completes the proof of the claim.

Now, using this claim with each row in the generalized form of the partial fractions expression, the theorem now holds. For a row iii in the partial fractions expression, one has eie_iei​ such polynomials from the claim- each of them will be multiplied by an rinr_i^nrin​ term and these can be factored to get rir_iri​ multiplied by the sum of eie_iei​ polynomials, of which the maixmum degree is ei−1e_i -1ei​−1 by the claim above. Let this sum of polynomials be the polynomial pi(x)p_i(x)pi​(x). This completes the proof of the theorem.

Now, this theorem gives us another way of quickly computing the coefficient of the xnx^nxn term in a quotient of polynomials. One knows the form that the quotient will take, so what remains is to plug whatever available information exists in the context into this theorem and then attempt to compute the coefficients of the polynomials p1,…,pkp_1, \dots, p_kp1​,…,pk​.
